arrests promised.\n\nThe string of violent incidents over the past few days began on Tuesday in Southport, after three girls were killed in a knife attack at a Taylor Swift-themed holiday club.\n\nHome Secretary Yvette Cooper said people involved in the clashes \"will pay the price\" and that \"criminal violence and disorder has no place on Britain's streets\".\n\nPrime Minister Sir Keir Starmer said the police have his \"full support\" to take action against \"extremists\" attempting to \"sow hate\" by intimidating communities as he held emergency talks with ministers over the unrest in parts of England.\n\nThe far right has drawn condemnation from MPs across the political spectrum after disorder in London, Manchester, Southport and Hartlepool came before Saturday's violence.\n\nArrests have been made across the country with police warning of more to come once CCTV, social media and body-worn camera footage has been scoured.\n\nJustice Secretary Shabana Mahmood told ministers \"the whole justice system is ready to deliver convictions as quickly as possible\", a Downing Street spokesperson said, which could see courts sitting for 24 hours a day as they did for the 2011 riots, according to one report.\n\nThere was violence on Saturday in towns and cities such as Hull, Liverpool, Stoke-on-Trent, Nottingham, Bristol, Manchester, Blackpool and Belfast which saw several police officers injured.\n\nIt followed a riot in Sunderland on Friday evening.\n\nCulture Secretary Lisa Nandy said anyone who attacks police \"should be ashamed\".\n\nShe wrote on X: \"I cannot thank our local police enough for everything they're doing to keep people safe.\n\nThey were among the first on the scene when the horrendous incident unfolded in Southport.\n\nThey run into danger to keep us safe, and those who attack them should be ashamed.\"\n\nNorthern Ireland's Deputy First Minister Emma Little-Pengelly said \"violence is not acceptable\".\n\n\"Northern Ireland must always be a place that protects the right to protest, the right to have a view and to express it\", she posted on X.\n\n\"Let's be VERY clear - violence is not acceptable. It never was and it is not now. No one, NO ONE, has the right to express hate and violence. Stop it now.\"\n\nIn Liverpool, Merseyside Police said about 300 people were involved in violent disorder on County Road, Walton, which included community facilities being set on fire.\n\nThe Spellow Lane Library Hub, which was opened last year to provide support for one of the most deprived communities in the country, suffered severe damage to the ground floor.\n\nPolice said rioters tried to prevent firefighters from accessing the fire, throwing a missile at the fire engine and breaking the rear window of the cab.\n\nA total of 23 people were arrested on Saturday, Merseyside Police said, including 12 arrests for the disorder in the city centre, nine arrests for the disorder on County Road and two arrests in connection with the disorder in Southport.\n\nOne officer was kicked and knocked off his motorcycle by a demonstrator and others tried to kick riot shields.\n\nAssistant Chief Constable Alex Goss called the behaviour of protesters \"deplorable\", adding: \"The impact of the disorder will be devastating for the people of Walton, but I promise that we are doing everything in our power to arrest those involved and bring them to justice.\"\n\nMerseyside Police also said a 58-year-old man has been charged with two offences following the violent disorder in Southport on Tuesday.\n\nDerek Drummond of Pool Street, Southport, has been charged with violent disorder and assault on an emergency worker. He will appear at Wirral Magistrates Court on Monday, August 5, police said.\n\nIn Hull, Humberside Police said there were 20 people arrested, three police officers injured and shops looted and burned after a mob attacked a hotel housing asylum seekers.\n\nAssistant Chief Constable Mike Walker said: \"The right to lawful protest is a part of democracy, which my officers upheld, however, we will not accept the senseless vandalism, antisocial behaviour and sheer violence that has been brought to our streets.\"\n\nBusinesses were targeted in Belfast where police mounted a significant security operation during a lengthy confrontation between anti-Islamic protesters and those taking part in an anti-racist rally at Belfast City Hall during which fireworks and other missiles were thrown.\n\nIn Bristol, police made 14 arrests because of violent disorder in the city centre, which Avon and Somerset Police described as \"completely unacceptable\".\n\nLancashire Police said more than 20 people were arrested and dispersal orders were issued in parts of Blackpool, Preston and Blackburn.\n\nAnd Staffordshire Police said 10 people were also arrested following disorder in Stoke-on-Trent.\n\nFurther protests are planned for Sunday and more trouble is likely in the coming days, police said.\n\n\"We know people will try and do this again and policing has been and will continue to be ready,\" said Chief Constable BJ Harrington, who speaks on public order for the National Police Chiefs' Council.\n\n\"There are 130 extra units in place across the country, meaning almost 4,000 extra public order-trained officers to deploy.\n\n\"So if you're planning to cause trouble and disorder our message is very simple - we'll be watching you.\"", "source": {"uri": He will appear at Wirral Magistrates Court on Monday, August 5, police said.\n\nIn Hull, Humberside Police said there were 20 people arrested, three police officers injured and shops looted and burned after a mob attacked a hotel housing asylum seekers.\n\nAssistant Chief Constable Mike Walker said: \"The right to lawful protest is a part of democracy, which my officers upheld, however, we will not accept the senseless vandalism, antisocial behaviour and sheer violence that has been brought to our streets.\"\n\nBusinesses were targeted in Belfast where police mounted a significant security operation during a lengthy confrontation between anti-Islamic protesters and those taking part in an anti-racist rally at Belfast City Hall during which fireworks and other missiles were thrown.\n\nLancashire Police said more than 20 people were arrested and dispersal orders were issued in parts of Blackpool, Preston and Blackburn.\n\nAnd Staffordshire Police said 10 people were also arrested following disorder in Stoke-on-Trent.\n\nFurther protests are planned for Sunday and more trouble is likely in the coming days, police said.\n\n\"We know people will try and do this again and policing has been and will continue to be ready,\" said Chief Constable BJ Harrington, who speaks on public order for the National Police Chiefs' Council.\n\n\"There are 130 extra units in place to give police forces the government's \"full support\" to take action against \"extremists\" attempting to \"sow hate\".\n\nTensions have been high after the killing of three young girls at a Taylor Swift-themed dance party in Southport, Merseyside, on Monday.\n\nIn Liverpool, bricks, bottles and a flare were thrown at police, one officer was hit in the head when a chair was thrown, and another was kicked and knocked off his motorbike.\n\nA few hundred anti-fascist demonstrators gathered across from Liverpool's Lime Street station at lunchtime, calling for unity and tolerance, chanting \"refugees are welcome here\" and \"Nazi scum, off our streets\".\n\nThey marched down to the city's riverside to confront around one thousand anti-immigration protestors - some of whom were shouting Islamophobic slurs.\n\nPolice in riot gear with dogs struggled to keep the two sides apart and reinforcements were called to try and maintain order.\n\nThe unrest continued into the early hours of Sunday morning, with fireworks launched towards police officers wearing riot gear.\n\nA library was set on fire in the Walton area of the city and rioters tried to prevent firefighters from putting it out, Merseyside Police said.\n\nShops were broken into and a number of wheelie bins were set on fire, it added.\n\nThe force confirmed a number of officers had been injured in what they described as \"serious disorder\", adding that two had been taken to hospital - one with a suspected broken nose and one with a suspected broken jaw.\n\nIt said 23 people had been arrested.\n\nAssistant Chief Constable Jenny Simms said: \"The disorder, violence and destruction has no place here in Merseyside, least of all after the tragic events that took place in Southport on Monday\".\n\n\"Those who engaged in this behaviour bring nothing but shame to themselves and this city. \"\n\nAt a meeting of government ministers earlier on Saturday, a spokesperson for Sir Keir Starmer said the PM told those assembled that \"the right to freedom of expression and the violent disorder we have seen are two very different things.\"\n\nHe added: \"there is no excuse for violence of any kind and reiterated that the government backs the police to take all necessary action to keep our streets safe\".\n\nOn Saturday, the home secretary also warned that anyone engaging in \"unacceptable disorder\" would face imprisonment and travel bans amongst other punishments, adding that \"sufficient\" prison places had been made available.\n\n\"Criminal violence and disorder has no place on Britain's streets,\" Yvette Cooper said.\n\nPolice have the government's full backing in taking action against those engaging in \"thuggery\", she added.\n\nIn Bristol, protesters and counter-protests were engaged in a standoff.\n\nOne group could be heard singing 'Rule Britannia', \"England 'til I die\" and \"we want our country back\", while the other side chanted \"refugees are welcome here\".\n\nBeer cans were been thrown at the anti-racism group, and some of the rival protesters were baton-charged by officers.\n\nAvon and Somerset Police said 14 people in the city had been arrested, with Chief Inspector Vicks Hayward-Melen anticipating there would be \"further arrests over the coming days\".\n\nIn Manchester, there were scuffles with police, and at least two arrests.\n\nWhile in Belfast, two people were arrested as protesters outside a mosque threw objects at members of the media and earlier smashed windows in a cafe.\n\nIn Bristol, officers on horseback lined up to protect a hotel housing asylum seekers from a demonstration\n\nIn Hull, protesters smashed a window at a hotel used to house asylum seekers, and bottles and eggs were thrown at police.\n\nCity Hall was placed on lockdown as the British Chess Championships took place inside.\n\nHumberside Police said three police officers had been injured and 20 people arrested after disorder in the city centre also saw shops ransacked and items set on fire.\n\nIn Blackpool, protesters faced off against punks attending Rebellion Festival. There was little police presence as skirmishes broke out between the two groups, with bottles and chairs thrown.\n\nLancashire Police said it had arrested more than 20 people. The force said its focus had been on Blackpool but there had also been \"minor disruption\" in Blackburn and Preston.\n\nIn Stoke-on-Trent, bricks were thrown at officers. Staffordshire Police said that two men at the centre of online claims they had been stabbed had actually been hit by an object that was thrown, and were not seriously injured.\n\nThe force said 10 people had been arrested and three officers suffered minor injuries.\n\nElsewhere Leicestershire Police arrested two people in Leicester city centre. And West Yorkshire Police said a protest on the Headrow in Leeds \"passed off largely without incident\", despite one arrest being made.\n\nNot all demonstrations held across the UK descended into violence on Saturday, and in some places protesters dispersed by the evening.\n\nSaturday's protests follow a night of violence in Sunderland on Friday, which saw four police officers hospitalised and 10 people arrested.\n\nHundreds of people rioted, beer cans and bricks were thrown at riot police outside a mosque and a Citizens Advice office was torched.\n\nTwelve people have been arrested in connection with the violence.\n\nThe BBC has identified at least 30 demonstrations being planned by far-right activists in the UK through the weekend, including a new protest in Southport.\n\nAn extra 70 prosecutors are on standby this weekend to charge people arrested in connection with violent disorder.\n\nShadow home secretary James Cleverly called on Sir Keir and home secretary to \"do more\" to restore public order and \"send a clear message to the thugs\".\n\nEarlier this week, the prime minister announced a new national violent disorder programme to help clamp down on violent groups by Other smaller demonstrations elsewhere did not turn violent.\n\nThe prime minister has pledged to give police forces the government's \"full support\" to take action against \"extremists\" attempting to \"sow hate\".\n\nTensions have been high after the killing of three young girls at a Taylor Swift-themed dance party in Southport, Merseyside, on Monday.\n\nIn Liverpool, bricks, bottles and a flare were thrown at police, one officer was hit in the head when a chair was thrown, and another was kicked and knocked off his motorbike.\n\nA few hundred anti-fascist demonstrators gathered across from Liverpool's Lime Street station at lunchtime, calling for unity and tolerance, chanting \"refugees are welcome here\" and \"Nazi scum, off our streets\".\n\nThey marched down to the city's riverside to confront around one thousand anti-immigration protestors - some of whom were shouting Islamophobic slurs.\n\nPolice in riot gear with dogs struggled to keep the two sides apart and reinforcements were called to try and maintain order.\n\nThe unrest continued into the early hours of Sunday morning, with fireworks launched towards police officers wearing riot gear.\n\nA library was set on fire in the Walton area of the city and rioters tried to prevent firefighters from putting it out, Merseyside Police said.\n\nShops were broken into and a number of wheelie bins were set on fire, it added.\n\nThe force confirmed a number of officers had been injured in what they described as \"serious disorder\", adding that two had been taken to hospital - one with a suspected broken nose and one with a suspected broken jaw.\n\nIt said 23 people had been arrested.\n\nAssistant Chief Constable Jenny Simms said: \"The disorder, violence and destruction has no place here in Merseyside, least of all after the tragic events that took place in Southport on Monday\".\n\n\"Those who engaged in this behaviour bring nothing but shame to themselves and this city. \"\n\nAt a meeting of government ministers earlier on Saturday, a spokesperson for Sir Keir Starmer said the PM told those assembled that \"the right to freedom of expression and the violent disorder we have seen are two very different things.\"\n\nHe added: \"there is no excuse for violence of any kind and reiterated that the government backs the police to take all necessary action to keep our streets safe\".\n\nOn Saturday, the home secretary also warned that anyone engaging in \"unacceptable disorder\" would face imprisonment and travel bans amongst other punishments, adding that \"sufficient\" prison places had been made available.\n\n\"Criminal violence and disorder has no place on Britain's streets,\" Yvette Cooper said.\n\nPolice have the government's full backing in taking action against those engaging in \"thuggery\", she added.\n\nIn Bristol, protesters and counter-protests were engaged in a standoff.\n\nOne group could be heard singing Rule Britannia, \"England 'til I die\" and \"we want our country back\", while the other side chanted \"refugees are welcome here\".\n\nBeer cans were thrown at the anti-racism group, and some of the rival protesters were baton-charged by officers.\n\nAvon and Somerset Police said 14 people in the city had been arrested, with Chief Inspector Vicks Hayward-Melen anticipating there would be \"further arrests over the coming days\".\n\nIn Manchester, there were scuffles with police, and at least two arrests.\n\nWhile in Belfast, two people were arrested as protesters outside a mosque threw objects at members of the media and earlier smashed windows in a cafe.\n\nIn Hull, protesters smashed a window at a hotel used to house asylum seekers, and bottles and eggs were thrown at police.\n\nCity Hall was placed on lockdown as the British Chess Championships took place inside.\n\nHumberside Police said three police officers had been injured and 20 people arrested after disorder in the city centre also saw shops ransacked and items set on fire.\n\nIn Blackpool, protesters faced off against punks attending Rebellion Festival. There was little police presence as skirmishes broke out between the two groups, with bottles and chairs thrown.\n\nLancashire Police said it had arrested more than 20 people. The force said its focus had been on Blackpool but there had also been \"minor disruption\" in Blackburn and Preston.\n\nIn Stoke-on-Trent, bricks were thrown at officers. Staffordshire Police said that two men at the centre of online claims they had been stabbed had actually been hit by an object that was thrown, and were not seriously injured.\n\nThe force said 10 people had been arrested and three officers suffered minor injuries.\n\nElsewhere Leicestershire Police arrested two people in Leicester city centre. And West Yorkshire Police said a protest on the Headrow in Leeds \"passed off largely without incident\", despite one arrest being made.\n\nNot all demonstrations held across the UK descended into violence on Saturday, and in some places protesters dispersed by the evening.\n\nSaturday's protests follow a night of violence in Sunderland on Friday, which saw four police officers hospitalised.\n\nHundreds of people rioted, beer cans and bricks were thrown at riot police outside a mosque and a Citizens Advice office was torched.\n\nTwelve people have been arrested in connection with the violence.\n\nThe BBC has identified at least 30 demonstrations being planned by far-right activists around the UK over the weekend, including a new protest in Southport.\n\nAn extra 70 prosecutors are on standby this weekend to charge people arrested in connection with violent disorder.\n\nShadow home secretary James Cleverly called on Sir Keir and the home secretary to \"do more\" to restore public order and \"send a clear message to the thugs\".\n\nEarlier this week, the prime minister announced a new national violent disorder programme to help clamp down on violent groups by persist", "body": "Police have resources they need, says minister as unrest threatens to persist\n\nNina Lloyd, PA Political Correspondent\n\n4 August 2024 at 11:20 am\n\nPolice have \"all the resources they need\" to deal with riots and disorder, a minister has said amid concerns over the prospect of further violence sweeping across parts of the country.\n\nCourts could sit for 24 hours to ensure \"thugs\" who \"maraud our streets\" are swiftly brought to justice, while forces have measures in place to draft in extra officers to respond to further unrest, Dame Diana Johnson has indicated.\n\nPrime Minister Sir Keir Starmer has given police his \"full backing\" to take any action necessary to respond to \"extremists\" attempting to \"sow hate\" after scenes of disorder in England and Northern Ireland this week.\n\nBut concerns have been raised that officers may be left unable to deal with other incidents as a result of the need to focus efforts on the prospect of ongoing rioting, with the Police Federation warning: \"There is a cost to all this.\"\n\nAsked whether enough is being done to respond to the disorder, policing minister Dame Diana said the Government has been \"reassured\" forces are able to meet the scale of the challenge.\n\n\"The police have made it very clear that they have all the resources they need at the moment... they have the powers that they need,\" the minister told BBC News.\n\n\"There is no need to bring in the Army and there has been no discussion about that.\n\n\"(Police) have long-standing plans in place for mutual aid if they need to put extra police officers into certain parts of the country.\"\n\nDespite the Government recently announcing the early release of some offenders to ease prison overcrowding, Dame Diana said there is jail capacity to hand custodial sentences to those \"marauding our streets\".\n\nAsked whether courts could be forced to sit overnight to fast-track prosecutions as they did for the 2011 riots, she said the Government will do \"whatever it takes\" to ensure people are brought to justice.\n\nDeputy national chair of the Police Federation, Brian Booth, told the PA news agency that forces can handle the unrest in the short-term, but it will likely put further pressure on already-stretched resources.\n\n\"There is a cost to all this,\" he said. \"Every day this continues means a certain amount of officer hours are being taken away from other policing duties. It has a massive effect on already significant under-resourcing.\"\n\nSome areas may see a diminished police presence as a result of less robust preventative patrols because officers \"can't be in two places at once\", he said.\n\nScanning CCTV and other footage in incident rooms to identify suspects and deploying to the scene of disorder means fewer staff on the beat, Mr Booth added.\n\nOfficers taken out by injuries will also deplete forces, he said, adding: \"It's truly awful. These are the images I never want to see, of colleagues being battered just for doing their job.\"\n\nThe far-right has drawn widespread condemnation as the organising force behind scenes of disorder in multiple towns and cities in the wake of the killings of three young girls in Southport on Monday.\n\nFalse claims had spread online that the suspect, later identified as a 17-year-old from Lancashire, was an asylum seeker who had arrived in the UK by boat.\n\nOfficers have been pelted with bricks, chairs and bottles, mosques have been attacked, and a police station in Sunderland along with a number of community facilities across the country have been torched in the violence.\n\nHome Secretary Yvette Cooper said people involved in the clashes \"will pay the price\" and that \"criminal violence and disorder has no place on Britain's streets\".\n\nArrests have been made across the country including in London, Hartlepool, Southport, Hull and Liverpool, and some charges have been brought, with police warning of more to come once footage has been scoured.\n\nSir Keir held crisis talks with ministers on Saturday over the unrest, with Justice Secretary Shabana Mahmood telling colleagues \"the whole justice system is ready to deliver convictions as quickly as possible\".\n\nThere was violence on Saturday in towns and cities such as Hull, Liverpool, Stoke-on-Trent, Nottingham, Bristol, Manchester, Blackpool and Belfast which saw several police officers injured.\n\nIn Liverpool, Merseyside Police said about 300 people were involved in violent disorder on County Road, Walton, which included community facilities being set on fire.\n\nThe Spellow Lane Library Hub, which was opened last year to provide support for one of the most deprived communities in the country, suffered severe damage to the ground floor.\n\nPolice said rioters tried to prevent firefighters from accessing the blaze, throwing a missile at the fire engine and breaking the rear window of the cab.\n\nA total of 23 people were arrested on Saturday, Merseyside Police said, including 12 arrests for the disorder in the city centre, nine arrests for the disorder on County Road and two arrests in connection with disorder in Southport.\n\nOne officer was kicked and knocked off his motorcycle by a demonstrator and others tried to kick riot shields.\n\nAssistant Chief Constable Alex Goss called the behaviour of protesters \"deplorable\", adding: \"The impact of the disorder will be devastating for the people of Walton, but I promise that we are doing everything in our power to arrest those involved and bring them to justice.\"\n\nIn Bristol, police made 14 arrests because of violent disorder in the city centre, which Avon and Somerset Police described as \"completely unacceptable\".\n\nLancashire Police said more than 20 people were arrested and dispersal orders were issued in parts of Blackpool, Preston and Blackburn.\n\nStaffordshire Police said 10 people were arrested following disorder in Stoke-on-Trent.\n\nFurther protests are planned for Sunday and more trouble is likely in the coming days, police said.\n\n\"We know people will try and do this again and policing has been and will continue to be ready,\" said Chief Constable BJ Harrington, who speaks on public order for the National Police Chiefs' Council.\n\n\"There are 130 extra units in place across the country, meaning almost 4,000 extra public order-trained officers to deploy.\n\n\"So if you're planning to cause trouble and disorder our message is very simple - we'll be watching you.\"", Lancashire Police said more than 20 people were arrested and dispersal orders were issued in parts of Blackpool, Preston and Blackburn.\n\nAnd Staffordshire Police said 10 people were also arrested following disorder in Stoke-on-Trent. disorder", "body": "Police have \"all the resources they need\" to deal with riots and disorder, a minister has said amid concerns over the prospect of further violence sweeping across parts of the country.\n\nCourts could sit for 24 hours to ensure \"thugs\" who \"maraud our streets\" are swiftly brought to justice, while forces have measures in place to draft in extra officers to respond to further unrest, Dame Diana Johnson has indicated.\n\nPrime Minister Sir Keir Starmer has given police his \"full backing\" to take any action necessary to respond to \"extremists\" attempting to \"sow hate\" after scenes of disorder in England and Northern Ireland this week.\n\nREAD MORE: Lancashire Police slam day of disorder as 'mindless thuggery' as more than 20 arrests made\n\nBut concerns have been raised that officers may be left unable to deal with other incidents as a result of the need to focus efforts on the prospect of ongoing rioting, with the Police Federation warning: \"There is a cost to all this.\"\n\nAsked whether enough is being done to respond to the disorder, policing minister Dame Diana said the Government has been \"reassured\" forces are able to meet the scale of the challenge.\n\n\"The police have made it very clear that they have all the resources they need at the moment... they have the powers that they need,\" the minister told BBC News.\n\n\"There is no need to bring in the Army and there has been no discussion about that.\n\n\"(Police) have long-standing plans in place for mutual aid if they need to put extra police officers into certain parts of the country.\"\n\nDespite the Government recently announcing the early release of some offenders to ease prison overcrowding, Dame Diana said there is jail capacity to hand custodial sentences to those \"marauding our streets\".\n\nAsked whether courts could be forced to sit overnight to fast-track prosecutions as they did for the 2011 riots, she said the Government will do \"whatever it takes\" to ensure people are brought to justice.\n\nDeputy national chair of the Police Federation, Brian Booth, told the PA news agency that forces can handle the unrest in the short-term, but it will likely put further pressure on already-stretched resources.\n\n\"There is a cost to all this,\" he said. \"Every day this continues means a certain amount of officer hours are being taken away from other policing duties. It has a massive effect on already significant under-resourcing.\"\n\nSome areas may see a diminished police presence as a result of less robust preventative patrols because officers \"can't be in two places at once\", he said.\n\nScanning CCTV and other footage in incident rooms to identify suspects and deploying to the scene of disorder means fewer staff on the beat, Mr Booth added.\n\nOfficers taken out by injuries will also deplete forces, he said, adding: \"It's truly awful. These are the images I never want to see, of colleagues being battered just for doing their job.\"\n\nThe far-right has drawn widespread condemnation as the organising force behind scenes of disorder in multiple towns and cities in the wake of the killings of three young girls in Southport on Monday.\n\nFalse claims had spread online that the suspect, later identified as a 17-year-old from Lancashire, was an asylum seeker who had arrived in the UK by boat.\n\nOfficers have been pelted with bricks, chairs and bottles, mosques have been attacked, and a police station in Sunderland along with a number of community facilities across the country have been torched in the violence.\n\nHome Secretary Yvette Cooper said people involved in the clashes \"will pay the price\" and that \"criminal violence and disorder has no place on Britain's streets\".\n\nArrests have been made across the country including in London, Hartlepool, Southport, Hull and Liverpool, and some charges have been brought, with police warning of more to come once footage has been scoured.\n\nSir Keir held crisis talks with ministers on Saturday over the unrest, with Justice Secretary Shabana Mahmood telling colleagues \"the whole justice system is ready to deliver convictions as quickly as possible\".\n\nThere was violence on Saturday in towns and cities such as Hull, Liverpool, Stoke-on-Trent, Nottingham, Bristol, Manchester, Blackpool and Belfast which saw several police officers injured.\n\nIn Liverpool, Merseyside Police said about 300 people were involved in violent disorder on County Road, Walton, which included community facilities being set on fire.\n\nThe Spellow Lane Library Hub, which was opened last year to provide support for one of the most deprived communities in the country, suffered severe damage to the ground floor.\n\nPolice said rioters tried to prevent firefighters from accessing the blaze, throwing a missile at the fire engine and breaking the rear window of the cab.\n\nA total of 23 people were arrested on Saturday, Merseyside Police said, including 12 arrests for the disorder in the city centre, nine arrests for the disorder on County Road and two arrests in connection with disorder in Southport.\n\nOne officer was kicked and knocked off his motorcycle by a demonstrator and others tried to kick riot shields.\n\nAssistant Chief Constable Alex Goss called the behaviour of protesters \"deplorable\", adding: \"The impact of the disorder will be devastating for the people of Walton, but I promise that we are doing everything in our power to arrest those involved and bring them to justice.\"\n\nIn Bristol, police made 14 arrests because of violent disorder in the city centre, which Avon and Somerset Police described as \"completely unacceptable\".\n\nLancashire Police said more than 20 people were arrested and dispersal orders were issued in parts of Blackpool, Preston and Blackburn.\n\nStaffordshire Police said 10 people were arrested following disorder in Stoke-on-Trent.\n\nFurther protests are planned for Sunday and more trouble is likely in the coming days, police said.\n\n\"We know people will try and do this again and policing has been and will continue to be ready,\" said Chief Constable BJ Harrington, who speaks on public order for the National Police Chiefs' Council.\n\n\"There are 130 extra units in place across the country, meaning almost 4,000 extra public order-trained officers to deploy.\n\n\"So if you're planning to cause trouble and disorder our message is very simple - we'll be watching you.\"\n\nSubscribe to our daily newsletter LANCS LIVE NEWS and get all the biggest stories from across Lancashire direct to your inbox", "source": {"uri": "lancs.live", "dataType": "news", "title": sweeping across parts of the country.\n\nCourts could sit for 24 hours to ensure \"thugs\" who \"maraud our streets\" are swiftly brought to justice, while forces have measures in place to draft in \"extremists\" attempting to \"sow hate\" after scenes of disorder in England and Northern Ireland this week.\n\nPolicing minister Dame Diana Johnson said the police have the resources they need (PA)\n\nBut concerns have been raised that officers may be left unable to deal with other incidents as a result of the need to focus efforts on the prospect of ongoing rioting, with the Police Federation warning: \"There is a cost to all this.\"\n\nAsked whether enough is being done to respond to the disorder, policing minister Dame Diana said the Government has been \"reassured\" forces are able to meet the scale of the challenge.\n\n\"The police have made it very clear that they have all the resources they need at the moment... they have the powers that they need,\" the minister told BBC News.\n\n\"There is no need to bring in the Army and there has been no discussion about that.\n\n\"(Police) have long-standing plans in place for mutual aid if they need to put extra police officers into certain parts of the country.\"\n\nDespite the Government recently announcing the early release of some offenders to ease prison overcrowding, Dame Diana said there is jail capacity to hand custodial sentences to those \"marauding our streets\".\n\nAsked whether courts could be forced to sit overnight to fast-track prosecutions as they did for the 2011 riots, she said the Government will do \"whatever it takes\" to ensure people are brought to justice.\n\nDeputy national chair of the Police Federation, Brian Booth, told the PA news agency that forces can handle the unrest in the short-term, but it will likely put further pressure on already-stretched resources.\n\n\"There is a cost to all this,\" he said. \"Every day this continues means a certain amount of officer hours are being taken away from other policing duties. It has a massive effect on already significant under-resourcing.\"\n\nSome areas may see a diminished police presence as a result of less robust preventative patrols because officers \"can't be in two places at once\", he said.\n\nScanning CCTV and other footage in incident rooms to identify suspects and deploying to the scene of disorder means fewer staff on the beat, Mr Booth added.\n\nOfficers taken out by injuries will also deplete forces, he said, adding: \"It's truly awful. These are the images I never want to see, of colleagues being battered just for doing their job.\"\n\nRiot police form a line on the Lower Ormeau Road amid unrest in Belfast (PA)\n\nThe far-right has drawn widespread condemnation as the organising force behind scenes of disorder in multiple towns and cities in the wake of the killings of three young girls in Southport on Monday.\n\nFalse claims Blackpool and Belfast which saw several police officers injured.\n\nA protest in Sunderland city centre (Scott Heppell/PA)\n\nIn Liverpool, Merseyside Police said about 300 people were involved in and breaking the rear window of the cab.\n\nA total of 23 people were arrested on Saturday, Merseyside Police said, including 12 arrests for the disorder in the city centre, nine arrests for the disorder on County Road and two arrests in connection with disorder in Southport.\n\nOne officer was kicked and knocked off his motorcycle by a demonstrator and others tried to kick riot shields.\n\nAssistant Chief Constable Alex Goss called the behaviour of protesters \"deplorable\", adding: \"The impact of the disorder will be devastating for the people of Walton, but I promise that we are doing everything in our power to arrest those involved and bring them to justice.\"\n\nIn Bristol, police made 14 arrests because of violent disorder in the city centre, which Avon and Somerset "Police have resources they need, says minister as unrest threatens to persist", "body": "Dame Diana Johnson said courts could sit for 24 hours to ensure 'thugs' who 'maraud our streets' are swiftly country.\n\nCourts could sit overnight to ensure \"thugs\" who \"maraud our streets\" are brought to justice, while forces have measures in place to draft in extra officers to tackle potential unrest, Dame Diana Johnson has indicated.\n\nPrime Minister Sir Keir Starmer has given police his \"full backing\" to take any action necessary to respond to \"extremists\" attempting to \"sow hate\" after scenes of disorder in England and Northern Ireland this week.\n\nBut concerns have been raised that officers may be left unable to deal with other incidents as a result of the need to focus efforts on the prospect of ongoing rioting, with the Police Federation warning: \"There is a cost to all this.\"\n\nMasked anti-immigration demonstrators smashed windows at a Holiday Inn Express in Rotherham, South Yorkshire, on Sunday.\n\nGreater Manchester Police said a Section 34 dispersal notice has been authorised covering Bolton until 10pm on Sunday, where a protest is expected later.\n\nTeams worked through the night to reopen streets in cities like Hull, where volunteers armed with brushes turned up from 7am to assist council crews.\n\n\"Yesterday we saw the worst of Hull but already today we have seen the best,\" councillor Jack Haines of Hull City Council said.\n\nAsked whether enough is being done to respond to the disorder, policing minister Dame Diana said the Government has been \"reassured\" that forces are able to meet the scale of the challenge.\n\n\"The police have made it very clear that they have all the resources they need at the moment... they have the powers that they need,\" the minister told BBC News.\n\n\"There is no need to bring in the Army and there has been no discussion about that.\n\n\"(Police) have long-standing plans in place for mutual aid if they need to put extra police officers into certain parts of the country.\"\n\nDespite the Government recently announcing the early release of some offenders to ease prison overcrowding, Dame Diana said there is jail capacity to hand custodial sentences to those \"marauding our streets\".\n\nAsked whether courts could be forced to sit overnight to fast-track prosecutions as they did for the 2011 riots, she said the Government will do \"whatever it takes\" to ensure people are brought to justice.\n\nDeputy national chair of the Police Federation, Brian Booth, told the PA news agency that forces can handle the unrest in the short-term, but it will likely put further pressure on already-stretched resources.\n\n\"There is a cost to all this,\" he said. \"Every day this continues means a certain amount of officer hours are being taken away from other policing duties. It has a massive effect on already significant under-resourcing.\"\n\nSome areas may see a diminished police presence as a result of less robust preventative patrols because officers \"can't be in two places at once\", he said.\n\nScanning CCTV and other footage in incident rooms to identify suspects and deploying to the scene of disorder means fewer staff on the beat, Mr Booth warned.\n\nOfficers taken out by injuries will also deplete forces, he said, adding: \"It's truly awful. in multiple towns and cities in the wake of the killings of three young girls in Southport on Monday.\n\nFalse claims had spread online that the suspect, later identified as 17-year-old Axel price\" and that \"criminal violence and disorder has no place on Britain's streets\".\n\nAt least 90 arrests have been made across the country and some charges have been brought, with police warning of more to come once footage has been scoured.\n\nSir Keir held crisis talks with ministers on Saturday over the unrest, with Justice Secretary Shabana Mahmood telling colleagues \"the whole justice to the ground floor.\n\nPolice said rioters tried to prevent firefighters from accessing the blaze, throwing a missile at the fire engine and breaking the rear window of the cab.\n\nA total of 23 There are consequences for breaking the law.\"\n\nThe widespread clashes pose the first big challenge to Keir Starmer's new government, which is facing demands to introduce emergency powers to stop further violence and to recall parliament.\n\nOn Saturday bricks were hurled at police officers in Stoke-on-Trent, fireworks were thrown amid tense exchanges between an anti-Islamic group and an anti-racism rally in Belfast, and windows of a hotel which has been used to house migrants were smashed in Hull, where three police officers were injured and four people arrested. Later video footage on social media showed shops on fire. Several officers were also injured during \"serious disorder\" in Liverpool city centre, where bricks, bottles and a flare were thrown and two officers needed hospital treatment and six arrests were made. Greater Manchester police said a dispersal notice had been authorised for the city centre. Scuffles broke out as opposing groups faced each other in Nottingham's Old Market Square with bottles and other items thrown from both sides.\n\nAbout 150 people carrying St George's Cross flags, shouting \"you're not English any more\" and \"paedo Muslims off our street\", were greatly outnumbered in Leeds by hundreds of counter-protesters shouting \"Nazi scum off our streets\". Skirmishes broke out between demonstrators and punks - in town for a festival - in Blackpool, with bottles and chairs thrown.\n\nIn Bristol, police kept protesters and counter protesters apart before a group headed to a hotel used to house asylum seekers.\n\nThe need for urgent political intervention was stressed by the government's independent adviser on political violence and disruption, Lord Walney, who told the Observer that new emergency powers may be needed. \"The system isn't set up to deal with this rolling rabble-rousing being fuelled by far-right actors,\" he said.\n\n\"I think home office ministers may want to look urgently at a new emergency framework - perhaps temporary in nature - that enables police to use the full powers of arrest to prevent people gathering where there is clear intent to fuel violent disorder.\"\n\nKeir Starmer held a meeting of senior ministers on Saturday in which he said police had been given full support to tackle extremists who were attempting \"to sow hate by intimidating communities\". He made clear that the right to freedom of expression and the violent scenes over recent days were \"two very different things\".\n\nLast week's riots followed the killing of three young girls at a Taylor Swift-themed dance class in Southport on Monday. Axel Rudakubana, 17, from Lancashire, is accused of the attack, but false claims were spread online that the suspect was an asylum seeker who had arrived in the UK by boat. In the wake of these messages, far-right protesters - guided by social media - gathered in cities across the country.\n\nA key factor in this spread of online disinformation involved Elon Musk's decision to allow rightwing activists such as Tommy Robinson back onto his social media platform X, said Joe Mulhall, director of research at Hope not Hate, the anti-fascism organisation. \"The initial disinformation and anger was being perpetrated by individuals on Twitter, for example, that have been previously deplatformed,\" he said. \"And now they've been replatformed.\"\n\nRobinson was permanently banned from the platform (then called Twitter) in March 2018, then reinstated in November last year, after Musk bought it. \"We hadn't seen any significant numbers at any demonstrations since 2018,\" Mulhall added.\n\nAn example of the danger posed by the misuse of social media was revealed in Stoke-on-Trent, where police were forced to deny there had been a stabbing, countering claims made on social media. \"There is growing speculation that a stabbing has taken place as a result of the disorder today. We can confirm this information is false and no stabbings have been reported to police or emergency responders, despite videos fuelling speculation on social media,\" police said.\n\nThe danger of such intervention was stressed by Ben-Julian \"BJ\" Harrington, the National Police Chiefs Council lead for public order, who condemned social media disinformation as a cause of last week's disorder.\n\nHe said: \"We had reports today that two people had been stabbed by Muslims in Stoke - it's just not true. There's people out there, not even in this country, circulating and stoking up hatred, division and concerns in communities that they don't care about, don't know and don't understand.\"\n\nHarrington, who was also the NPCC's gold commander in charge of national strategy for Saturday's disorder, said that \"yobs and thugs and criminals\" were responsible. \"This isn't about protests,\" he said. \"This is about violent disorder. This is about people who are descending into communities and causing damage - throwing bricks and bottles and things at cops who work within those communities.\"\n\nForces across England brought officers back from leave to deploy an extra 130 police support units - about 2,000 officers, he revealed. \"Of course there is a limited number of officers, and every one that is taken from a community is not out there solving burglaries.\"\n\nEchoing concerns about the dangers of social media, shadow home secretary James Cleverly called for tech companies to be hauled into Downing Street to ensure they were acting to stop the spread of disinformation on their platforms. However, he was criticised for issuing a statement in which he said Starmer taking the knee had sent \"completely the wrong message\" to protesters, adding that there was \"never a justification for disorder like this\".\n\nThere was also further condemnation of Nigel Farage's role in inciting the violence with his comments about the Southport killings, in which he questioned \"whether the truth is being withheld from us\" after the attack on Monday. Robert Jenrick, one of the favourites in the Tory leadership race, said that the Reform leader's comments did not \"make the situation better\".\n\nLast week's clashes spread four days ago, when more than 100 protesters were arrested on Whitehall, where bottles and cans were thrown at police, while violence also broke out in Hartlepool and in Manchester.\n\nOn Thursday, Starmer announced a new \"national\" response to the disorder linking police forces across the country through shared intelligence and the expanded use of facial recognition.\n\nThen, on Friday, about 500 people, including some parents with their children, gathered in Sunderland city centre, responding to far-right social media posts to turn up and demonstrate. The gathering quickly descended into violence, with masked boys and men throwing missiles, including bricks, stones, beer barrels and scaffolding poles, at riot police.\n\nTen people were arrested and four policemen taken to hospital, one seriously injured. A police station was ransacked and a Citizens Advice Bureau set alight. By Saturday morning, the acrid smell of fire still hung in the air. Shoppers stopped to express their shock at what had happened, with hundreds of residents of all ages gathering on the city's streets with brushes, litter pickers, buckets, bin bags and dust pans.\n\nThe Sunderland Central Labour MP, Lewis Atkinson, said a link could be drawn between the disorder and the ashes of the English Defence League (EDL), which was founded by Robinson, whose real name is Stephen Yaxley-Lennon. The EDL has disbanded but its supporters remain active, and Atkinson said evidence suggested a neo-Nazi offshoot of the group was involved in Friday's violence.\n\nA priest at Sunderland Minster said yobs tried to smash a gravestone to use as missiles during the disorder that gripped the city. \"It's an act of sacrilege to disturb someone's gravestone,\" said Rev Jacqui Tyson. \"It's also There are consequences for breaking the law.\"\n\nThe widespread nature of the clashes poses the first major challenge to Keir Starmer's new government, which is now facing demands to introduce emergency powers to stop further violence and to recall parliament.\n\nIn the protests that spread across the nation, bricks were hurled at police officers in Stoke-on-Trent, fireworks were thrown amid tense exchanges between an anti-Islamic group and an anti-racism rally in Belfast, and windows of a hotel which has been used to house migrants were smashed in Hull, where three police officers were injured and four people arrested. Several officers were also injured during \"serious disorder\" in Liverpool city centre, where bricks, bottles and a flare were thrown and one officer hit on the head with a chair. Greater Manchester police said a dispersal notice had been authorised for the city centre and scuffles broke out as opposing groups faced each other in Nottingham's Old Market Square with bottles and other items thrown from both sides.\n\nAbout 150 people carrying St George's Cross flags, shouting \"you're not English any more\" and \"paedo Muslims off our street\", were greatly outnumbered in Leeds by hundreds of counter-protesters shouting \"Nazi scum off our streets\". Skirmishes broke out between demonstrators and punks - in town for a festival - in Blackpool, with bottles and chairs being thrown.\n\nThe need for urgent political intervention was stressed by the government's independent adviser on political violence and disruption, Lord Walney, who told the Observer that new emergency powers may be needed to deal with the outbreaks of violence. \"The system isn't set up to deal with this rolling rabble rousing being fuelled by far-right actors,\" he said.\n\n\"I think home office ministers maywant to look urgently at a new emergency framework - perhaps temporary in nature - that enables police to use the full powers of arrest to prevent people gathering where there is clear intent to fuel violent disorder.\"\n\nKeir Starmer held a meeting of senior ministers on Saturday in which he said police had been given full support to tackle extremists who were attempting \"to sow hate by intimidating communities\". He also made it clear that the right to freedom of expression and the violent scenes over recent days were \"two very different things\".\n\nLast week's riots were set off in the wake of the killing of three young girls at a Taylor Swift-themed dance class in Southport on Monday. Axel Rudakubana, 17, from Lancashire, is accused of the attack, but false claims were spread online that the suspect was an asylum seeker who had arrived in the UK by boat. In the wake of these messages, far-right protesters - guided by social media - gathered in cities across the country.\n\nA key factor in this spread of online disinformation involved Elon Musk's decision to allow rightwing activists such as Tommy Robinson back onto his social media platform X, said Joe Mulhall, director of research at Hope not Hate, the anti-fascism organisation. \"The initial disinformation and anger was being perpetrated by individuals on Twitter, for example, that have been previously deplatformed,\" he said. \"And now they've been replatformed.\"\n\nRobinson was permanently banned from the platform (then called Twitter) in March 2018, then reinstated in November last year, after Musk bought it. \"We hadn't seen any significant numbers at any demonstrations since 2018,\" Mulhall added.\n\nAn example of the danger posed by the misuse of social media was revealed in Stoke-on-Trent, where police were forced to deny there had been a stabbing there, countering claims made on social media. \"There is growing speculation that a stabbing has taken place as a result of the disorder today. We can confirm this information is false and no stabbings have been reported to police or emergency responders, despite videos fuelling speculation on social media,\" police said.\n\nThe danger of such intervention was stressed by Ben-Julian \"BJ\" Harrington, the National Police Chiefs Council lead for public order, who condemned social media disinformation as a cause of last week's disorder.\n\nHe said: \"We had reports today that two people had been stabbed by Muslims in Stoke - it's just not true. There's people out there, not even in this country, circulating and stoking up hatred, division and concerns in communities that they don't care about, don't know and don't understand.\"\n\nHarrington, who was also the NPCC's gold commander in charge of national strategy for Saturday's disorder, said that \"yobs and thugs and criminals\" were responsible. \"This isn't about protests,\" he said. \"This is about violent disorder. This is about people who are descending into communities and causing damage - throwing bricks and bottles and things at cops who work within those communities.\"\n\nForces across England brought officers back from leave to deploy an extra 130 police support units - about 2,000 officers, he revealed. \"Of course there is a limited number of officers, and every one that is taken from a community is not out there solving burglaries.\n\nEchoing concerns about the dangers of social media, shadow home secretary James Cleverly called for tech companies to be hauled into Downing Street to ensure they were acting to stop the spread of disinformation on their platforms. However, he was criticised for issuing a statement in which he said Starmer taking the knee had sent \"completely the wrong message\" to protesters, adding that there was \"never a justification for disorder like this\".\n\nThere was also further condemnation of Nigel Farage's role in inciting the violence with his comments about the Southport killings, in which he questioned \"whether the truth is being withheld from us\" after the attack on Monday. Robert Jenrick, one of the favourites in the Tory leadership race, said that the Reform leader's comments did not \"make the situation better\".\n\nLast week's clashes spread four days ago, when more than 100 protesters were arrested on Whitehall, where bottles and cans were thrown at police, while violence also broke out in Hartlepool and in Manchester.\n\nOn Thursday, Starmer announced a new \"national\" response to the disorder linking police forces across the country through shared intelligence and the expanded use of facial recognition.\n\nThen, on Friday, about 500 people, including some parents with their children, gathered in Sunderland city centre, responding to far-right social media posts to turn up and demonstrate. The gathering quickly descended into violence, with masked boys and men throwing missiles, including bricks, stones, beer barrels and scaffolding poles, at riot police.\n\nTen people were arrested and four policemen taken to hospital, one seriously injured. A police station was ransacked and a Citizens Advice Bureau set alight. By Saturday morning, the acrid smell of fire still hung in the air. Shoppers stopped to express their shock at what had happened, with hundreds of residents of all ages gathering on the city's streets with brushes, litter pickers, buckets, bin bags and dust pans.\n\nSunderland Central Labour MP Lewis Atkinson said a link could be drawn between the disorder and the ashes of the English Defence League (EDL), which was founded by Robinson, whose real name is Stephen Yaxley-Lennon. The EDL has disbanded but its supporters remain active, and Atkinson said evidence suggested a Nazi offshoot of the group was involved in Friday's violence.\n\nA priest at Sunderland Minster said yobs tried to smash a gravestone to use as missiles during the disorder that gripped the city. \"It's an act of sacrilege to disturb someone's gravestone,\" said Rev Jacqui Tyson. \"It's also remarkably Last night (August 3) thousands took to Bristol's streets with several causing mass disorder. Sixteeen people have currently been arrested and police say more arrests should follow after video footage has been reviewed.\n\nNow a similar protest had been organised for 7pm on Monday, August 5, at Plymouth's Guildhall. Slogans like \"stop the boats\", \"your country needs you\" and \"keep our children safe\" are being used to publicise the demonstration. In response, counter-protesters have planned to meet in the same location an hour earlier to put a stop to it, as PlymouthLive reports.\n\nOrganisers say: \"We must have the largest numbers possible for a counter-protest. That means we're calling everyone to Guildhall Square, Royal Parade, from 6pm with placards (some will need to be made) against racism and fascism, and banners from organisations wherever possible\".\n\nThey add: \"We've done it before in Plymouth and we'll do it again. Refugees are welcome here!\" It comes as a minister said police have \"all the resources they need\" to deal with riots and disorder.\n\nIt comes amid rising concerns over the prospect of further violence sweeping across parts of the country. Courts could sit overnight to ensure \"thugs\" who \"maraud our streets\" are brought to justice, while forces have measures in place to draft in extra officers to tackle potential unrest, Dame Diana Johnson has indicated.\n\nPrime Minister Sir Keir Starmer has given police his \"full backing\" to take any action necessary to respond to \"extremists\" attempting to \"sow hate\" after scenes of the Government has been \"reassured\" that forces are able to meet the scale of the challenge.\n\n\"The police have made it very clear that they have all the resources they need at the moment... they have the powers that they need,\" the minister told BBC News. \"There is no need to bring in the Army and there has been no discussion about that.\n\n\"(Police) have long-standing plans in place for Dame Diana said there is jail capacity to hand custodial sentences to those \"marauding our streets\".\n\nAsked whether courts could be forced to sit overnight to fast-track prosecutions as they did for the 2011 riots, she said the Government will do \"whatever it takes\" to ensure people are brought to justice.\n\nDeputy national chair of the Police Federation, Brian Booth, told the PA news agency that forces can handle the unrest in the short-term, but it will likely put further pressure on already-stretched resources.\n\n\"There is a cost to all this,\" he said. \"Every day this continues means a certain amount of officer hours are being taken away from other policing duties. It has a massive effect on already significant under-resourcing.\"\n\nSome areas may see a diminished police presence as a result of less robust preventative patrols because officers \"can't be in two places at once\", he said.\n\nThere was violence on Saturday in towns and cities such as Hull, Liverpool, Stoke-on-Trent, Nottingham, Bristol, Manchester, Blackpool and Belfast which saw several police officers injured. At least 100 arrests have been made across the country and some charges have been brought, with police warning of more to come once footage has been scoured.\n\nSir Keir held crisis talks with ministers on Saturday over the unrest, with Justice Secretary Shabana Mahmood telling colleagues \"the whole justice system is ready to deliver convictions as quickly as possible\".\n\nIn Liverpool, Merseyside Police said about 300 people were involved in violent disorder on County Road, Walton, which included community facilities being set on fire.\n\nIn Bristol, police made 14 arrests because of violent disorder in the city centre, which Avon and Somerset Police described as \"completely unacceptable\". Lancashire Police said more than 20 people were arrested and dispersal orders were issued in parts of Blackpool, Preston and Blackburn.\n\nStaffordshire Police said 10 people were arrested following disorder in Stoke-on-Trent. Further protests are planned for Sunday and more trouble is likely in the coming days, police said.\n\nTeams worked through the night to reopen streets in cities like Hull, where volunteers armed with brushes turned up from 7am to assist council crews.\n\n\"Yesterday we saw the worst of Hull but already today we have seen the best,\" councillor Jack Haines of Hull City Council said. \"We know people will try and do this again and policing has been and will continue to be ready,\" said Chief Constable BJ Harrington, who speaks on public order for the National Police Chiefs' Council.\n\n\"There are 130 extra units in place across the country, meaning almost 4,000 extra public order-trained officers to deploy. Prime Minister Keir Starmer has faced calls to recall Parliament after gangs of far-right yobs caused chaos again at the weekend, including in Rotherham, where mobs attacked a Holiday Inn Express housing asylum seekers. Here's a map of every area hit by rioting so far:\n\nWhy are the riots happening?\n\nMany of the protests have been organised and agitated online by members of the far-right, with lists of planned demonstrations appearing on social media late last week. Some of these lists also included further dates over the next few days, including protests at the Grey's Monument in Newcastle and at the Bullring in Birmingham.\n\nThe first signs of violence were seen in Southport last Tuesday, before a large 'Enough is Enough' protest in London was followed by several days of disorder in England and Northern Ireland. A total of 147 arrests were made in the weekend's disorder by Sunday afternoon, and this number is expected to rise as police track down those responsible.\n\nFormer home secretary Dame Priti Patel, Labour MPs including Diane Abbott and Dawn Butler, and Reform UK leader Nigel Farage have all called for the Commons to cut short its recess as the country endured another night of violence on Sunday. Home Secretary Yvette Cooper said on Monday that Parliament would not be recalled \"right now\".\n\nWhere did riots happen at the weekend?\n\nBelfast\n\nA small group of protesters gathered in front of City Hall on Saturday and chanted \"Islam Out.\" Fireworks were later thrown between the group and anti-racism demonstrators in the city, and some local businesses were attacked. Two people were arrested in connection with the disorder.\n\nBolton\n\nSmoke bombs and mounted police were used to try and quell disorder in Bolton on Sunday, where clashes erupted between protesters holding England flags and another group of around 250 men, some of whom were heard chanting \"Allahu Akbar\". Greater Manchester Police issued a Section 60AA order, requiring people to \"remove face coverings used to disguise or conceal their appearance\".\n\nBlackburn\n\nA dispersal order was enforced across Blackburn town centre on Saturday amid concerns that violence would erupt across the town. Blackburn MP Adnan Hussain urged people to stay away from the protest and echoed concerns about an escalation leading to clashes. A small anti-immigrant protest lasted for less than half an hour, according to the Lancashire Telegraph. One arrest has been made.\n\nBlackpool\n\nTwenty people were arrested in Blackpool after a demonstration turned violent on Saturday. ACC Phil Davies, of Lancashire Police, described the disorder as \"mindless thuggery\".\n\nBristol\n\nDemonstrators and counter-protesters faced off at the city's Castle Park on Saturday evening. Avon and Somerset Police obtained extra powers to stop, search and disperse people in the city centre due to the demonstrations. Police later said they had made 16 arrests over violent disorder in the city centre.\n\nHull\n\nShops including a Shoezone were looted and hotel windows smashed in ugly scenes in Hull on Saturday. Rioters were also seen trying to push through police barricades. Images taken at the scene showed police carrying riot shields as a crowd looked on from a distance. Four people have been arrested.\n\nLiverpool\n\nFar-right activists clashed with riot police along The Strand, close to the city's Liverpool One shopping centre on Saturday. Police were hit with bricks and several other objects during the demonstration, and the Spellow Hub library was also torched. Merseyside Police said several officers had been injured during the violent clashes. Police later tried to push demonstrators towards the Albert Docks, an area visited by many tourists. A total of 33 people have been arrested in connection with the disorder.\n\nManchester\n\nFight broke out in the city centre on Saturday. Police officers tried to keep demonstrators apart, but video showed scuffles breaking out in Piccadilly Gardens. A Sainsbury's was stormed by a gang of masked people, and several of them were heard chanting the name of far-right activist Tommy Robinson. Arrests were made by police.\n\nMiddlesbrough\n\nA group of rioters in Middlesbrough smashed the windows of houses, burnt cars and threw objects at officers on Sunday afternoon, with one seen shouting a racial slur and another telling police: \"It's our f****** country.\" There were 43 arrests, and significant damage was caused to the Crown Court and the University, Cleveland Police said.\n\nNottingham\n\nFar-right and counter-protesters threw objects at one another in the centre of Nottingham. Many of the people involved at the initial protest left and were replaced by people who had no affiliation to either group. Police held both groups away from one another during the majority of the protest, according to local reports. 15 people have been arrested\n\nRotherham\n\nIn some of the worst scenes of the entire weekend, anti-immigration rioters smashed the windows of a Holiday Inn Express believed to be housing asylum seekers before starting several fires. At least 10 officers were injured, including one who was knocked unconscious, South Yorkshire Police confirmed, saying one person had already been arrested and others involved should \"expect us to be at their doors very soon\".\n\nDefence Secretary John Healey, who is the local MP, arrived at the scene on Monday to talk to residents about \"the damage they have suffered and the trauma they have suffered\". Mr Healey said: \"This was an estate yesterday that was wracked with shock and fear. Many people in this estate here got holed up in their own homes or felt that they had to get their families out.\"\n\nPortsmouth\n\nHundreds of anti-immigration protesters were met with counter protesters at the steps of the Guildhall on Saturday. It is estimated about 300 people gathered for the short protest this morning. Police scuffled with protesters as they tried to break up a chase.\n\nStoke-on-Trent\n\nFour men were arrested in Stoke-on-Trent following disorder in the city on Saturday. Police were forced to deny speculation spreading on social media about a person being stabbed.\n\nIn a statement, Staffordshire Police said: \"There is growing speculation that a stabbing has taken place as a result of the disorder today. We can confirm this information is false and no stabbings have been reported to police or emergency responders, despite videos fuelling speculation on social media.\n\n\"We can confirm a man was injured after being hit by a blunt object that was thrown. His injuries are not thought to be serious and he has been taken to hospital for treatment. Four men have been arrested in connection with the disorder and are currently in custody for questioning.\n\nSunderland\n\nA police station was burnt in Sunderland on Friday as a planned demonstration quickly turned violent. Damage was also caused across the city centre. Six people have been charged in connection with the disorder.\n\nTamworth\n\nA Holiday Inn hotel was also attacked in Tamworth on Sunday evening, where reports suggested asylum seekers were being housed. Dispersal notices were issued across the city centre, and scuffles broke out in Nottingham's Old Market Square as opposing groups faced each other, with bottles and other objects thrown from both sides.\n\nPeople walk past Sunderland Central Police Station after a violent anti-immigrant protest in Sunderland on August 3. Photograph: Hollie Adams/Reuters\n\nAround 150 people carrying St George's Cross flags and chanting \"You are not British any more\" and \"Paedophile Muslims in our streets\" were heavily outnumbered in Leeds as hundreds of counter-protesters chanted Nazi rubbish in our streets. Clashes broke out between protesters and punks in the town for the festival in Blackpool, with bottles and chairs thrown.\n\nLord Walney, the government's independent adviser on political violence and disorder, has stressed the need for urgent political intervention. He told the Observer that new emergency powers may be needed to deal with outbreaks of violence. He said the system was not set up to deal with these raucous mobs, which were being fomented by far-right actors.\n\nHome Office ministers are expected to urgently consider new temporary emergency arrangements to allow police to use their full powers of arrest to address gatherings where there is a clear intention to cause violent disorder.\n\nKeir Starmer opened a meeting of senior ministers on Saturday, saying he was giving police full support to crack down on extremists who seek to spread hate by terrorising communities. He also made it clear that the right to freedom of expression and the violence of recent days were two very different things.\n\nThe riots last week began on Monday after three young girls were killed at a Taylor Swift-themed dance class in Southport. Axel Rudakubana, 17, from Lancashire, was suspected of the attack, but false claims spread online that the suspect was an asylum seeker who had arrived in the UK by boat. Following those messages, far-right protesters, guided by social media, gathered in cities across the country.\n\nJoe Mulhall, research director for the anti-fascist group Hope Not Hate, said Elon Musk's decision to allow right-wing activists like Tommy Robinson back onto his social media platform X was a major factor in the spread of online misinformation. He said individuals who had previously been banned from Twitter were the ones who spread the initial misinformation and outrage. And now they've been brought back onto the platform.\n\nRobinson was permanently banned from the platform (then called Twitter) in March 2018, but returned in November after Musk took over. Mulhall added that he hasn't seen significant numbers of people protesting since 2018.\n\nAn example of the dangers of misuse of social media was revealed in Stoke-on-Trent, where police were forced to deny that a stabbing had taken place there, contradicting claims made on social media. Speculation today that the disorder had led to a stabbing incident has grown. Police have confirmed that despite a video on social media fuelling speculation, the information is false and that no stabbing incident was reported to police or emergency responders.\n\nBen Julian BJ Harrington, head of public order for the National Police Chiefs' Council, highlighted the dangers of such interventions, blaming social media misinformation for last week's chaos.\n\nHe said: There were reports today that two people were stabbed by Muslims in Stoke. That is not true. There are people who do not even exist in this country, going around and spreading hate, division and concern about communities they do not care about, do not know about and do not understand.\n\nHarrington, who was also the NPCC's gold commander for the national strategy on Saturday disorder, said rioters, thugs and criminals were responsible. He said this was not about protests. This was about violent disorder. This was about people going into communities and throwing bricks and bottles at police officers working in those communities and causing damage.\n\nSkip newsletter promotions\n\nAnalysis and opinion on the week's news and culture from top Observer writers.\n\nPrivacy Notice: Our newsletter may contain information about charities, online advertising, and externally funded content. Of course, police numbers are limited and not all officers pulled from the community will be there to solve robberies.\n\nReflecting concerns about the dangers of social media, Shadow Home Secretary James Cleverley called on tech companies to be taken to Downing Street to ensure they were taking action to stop the spread of misinformation on their platforms. But he was criticised for issuing a statement saying Starmer's kneeling sent the wrong message to protesters, adding that there was absolutely no justification for such disorder.\n\nThere were also accusations that Nigel Farage had played a role in inciting violence with his comments about the Southport murders, and he questioned whether the truth was being hidden from us after Monday's attack. Robert Jenrick, one of the leading candidates in the Conservative leadership race, said the Reform Party leaders' comments had not made things any better.\n\nClashes last week escalated four days ago in Whitehall when more than 100 protesters were arrested and bottles and cans were thrown at police, while violence also broke out in Hartlepool and Manchester.\n\nStarmer announced a new national response to the problem on Thursday, linking police forces across the country through intelligence sharing and expanding facial recognition technology.\n\nThen on Friday, around 500 people, including parents with children, gathered in Sunderland city centre to protest against far-right social media posts. The gathering soon turned violent, with masked boys and men throwing missiles at riot police, including bricks, stones, beer cans and scaffolding poles.\n\nTen people were arrested and four police officers were taken to hospital, one seriously. A police station was looted and a citizens' counselling centre was set on fire. The smell of burning smoke still lingered in the air Saturday morning. Shoppers stopped to express their shock at what had happened, and hundreds of residents of all ages gathered on the city streets, carrying brushes, trash pickers, buckets, garbage bags and dustbins.\n\nSunderland Central Labour MP Louise Atkinson said there was a link between the disorder and the resurgence of the English Defence League (EDL), which was founded by Robinson, whose real name was Stephen Jabley-Lennon. The EDL has since disbanded but its supporters remain active, and Atkinson said there was evidence that the group's Nazi wing was involved in Friday's violence.\n\nA Sunderland cathedral priest said the mob had tried to tear down a headstone to use as a missile during the chaos gripping the city. On Saturday, dozens of people were arrested as demonstrations from Liverpool to Belfast descended into violence.\n\nSunday saw a new wave of clashes, with groups gathering in Rotherham, Bolton, Hull, Southport, Middlesbrough and other towns and cities scattered across the country that devolved into varying degrees of violence.\n\nIn Rotherham, protesters smashed windows and set fires at a Holiday Inn before storming into the building as riot police officers struggled to control the rampaging crowd. It is organized, violent thuggery.\"\n\nThe crisis has emerged as the first test for Mr. Starmer's fledgling Labour government, which scrambled on Sunday to tamp down reports that he was set to go on vacation this week. His office said he was not scheduled to be out of town and would remain at 10 Downing Street to manage the fallout.\n\nMainstream politicians from across the spectrum have been united in condemning the violence. Rishi Sunak, the former prime minister and current leader of the opposition Conservative Party, which had governed Britain for the last 14 years, said on X that the strife had \"nothing to do with the tragedy in Southport\" and that the police had \"our full support to deal with these criminals swiftly.\"\n\nTension has gripped some communities since a knife attack at a Taylor Swift-themed dance class left three young girls dead. Eight other children and two adults were wounded in the town of Southport, near Liverpool, and a 17-year-old suspect was later named.\n\nDisinformation about the attacker's identity spread quickly online, falsely identifying him as a recently arrived asylum seeker and fueling a far-right riot in which a mosque was attacked and dozens of police officers were hurt in Southport on Tuesday.\n\nThe wave of protests and unrest has been driven by fast-spreading misinformation, much of it promulgated by far-right voices on the social media platform X and the Telegram messaging app. They include neo-Nazis, violent soccer fans, anti-Muslim factions, and social media influencers who have amplified their messaging to followers.\n\nPockets of disorder have since cropped up in other parts of Britain, with violent protests in Liverpool, Manchester, Leeds, Nottingham and other cities over the weekend. A protest was also held in Belfast, Northern Ireland, and also turned violent.\n\nBJ Harrington, the head of public order for Britain's National Police Chiefs' Council, said that disinformation had been \"a huge driver of this appalling violence\" and that many who were involved were responding directly to what they had read online.\n\n\"Often posts are being shared and amplified by high-profile accounts,\" he said.\n\n\"We're working hard to counteract this,\" he said, adding, \"They won't win.\"\n\nMr. Harrington added that the disorder had declined significantly on Sunday. He also issued a warning for those stoking the disorder.\n\n\"Intelligence teams, detectives and neighborhood officers are working round the clock to identify and apprehend those involved,\" he said. \"And make no mistake, if you haven't had a knock on the door yet, your time will come.\"\n\nOn Saturday, larger groups had gathered in areas of unrest. In Liverpool, more than 300 people were involved in what the police called a \"violent disorder,\" when businesses were looted and rioters hurled bricks and other projectiles at police officers. Two police officers were taken to the hospital with non-life-threatening injuries. By Sunday morning, at least 11 people had been arrested, the police said.\n\nFar-right protesters and counterprotesters also clashed in Manchester, at least 10 people were arrested in unrest in Stoke-on-Trent, and there were clashes in Leeds, where the police said they had made a \"handful\" of arrests.\n\nIn Belfast, Northern Ireland, where anti-immigration messaging has also simmered, clashes broke out between anti-Muslim protesters and people at an antiracist demonstration at City Hall, with fireworks and projectiles being hurled between the two. have been attacking police officers, looting local shops or attacking people based on the color of their skin,\" Ms. Cooper said in a written statement.\n\nThe new security provisions have already begun, she said, and specific security for mosques across the country was already being provided this weekend, in addition to the police response.\n\n\"As a nation, we will not tolerate criminal
