More info\n\nA new map has detailed the exact locations of riots across the UK, as concerns rise over the disorder spreading to more parts of the country.\n\nThe country has been gripped by six days of mass disorder in towns and cities following the Southport stabbings last week, which resulted in three children being killed and eight injured during an attack on a dance class.\n\nPrime Minister Keir Starmer is facing calls to recall Parliament after far-right gangs caused chaos again at the weekend, including in Rotherham, where mobs attacked a Holiday Inn Express housing asylum seekers.\n\nHere's a map of every area hit by rioting so far:\n\nWhy are the riots happening?\n\nMany of the protests have been organised and stirred up online by members of the far-right, with lists of planned demonstrations appearing on social media late last week. Some of these lists also included further dates over the next few days, including protests at the Grey's Monument in Newcastle and at the Bullring in Birmingham.\n\nThe first scenes of violence were witnessed in Southport last Tuesday, before a large 'Enough is Enough' protest in London was followed by several days of disorder in England and Northern Ireland. A total of 147 arrests were made in the weekend's disorder by Sunday afternoon, and this number is expected to rise as police track down those responsible.\n\nThe weekend saw violence flare in a number of UK towns and cities, with police making a number of arrests. Here's a roundup of where trouble broke out.\n\nBelfast\n\nA small group of protesters gathered in front of City Hall on Saturday and chanted \"Islam Out.\"\n\nFireworks were later thrown between the group and anti-racism demonstrators in the city, and some local businesses were attacked. Two people were arrested in connection with the disorder.\n\nBolton\n\nSmoke bombs and mounted police were used to try and quell disorder in Bolton on Sunday, where clashes erupted between protesters holding England flags and another group of around 250 men, some of whom were heard chanting \"Allahu Akbar\". Greater Manchester Police issued a Section 60AA order, requiring people to \"remove face coverings used to disguise or conceal their appearance\".\n\nBlackburn\n\nA dispersal order was enforced across Blackburn town centre on Saturday amid concerns that violence would erupt across the town. Blackburn MP Adnan Hussain urged people to stay away from the protest and echoed concerns about an escalation leading to clashes.\n\nA small anti-immigrant protest lasted for less than half an hour, according to the Lancashire Telegraph. One arrest has been made.\n\nBlackpool\n\nIn Blackpool, twenty individuals were detained following a protest that escalated into violence on Saturday. ACC Phil Davies of Lancashire Police condemned the turmoil as \"mindless thuggery\".\n\nBristol\n\nIn Bristol, skirmishes erupted between demonstrators and counter-protesters at Castle Park on Saturday evening. Avon and Somerset Police were granted extended powers to stop and search, and disperse individuals in the city centre amidst the protests.\n\nThe police force later announced the arrest of 16 persons linked to violent disorder within the central area.\n\nHull\n\nHull witnessed scenes of chaos as businesses such as Shoezone were pillaged and hotel windows shattered during the tumult on Saturday. Rioters also attempted to overcome police blockades.\n\nPhotographs from the scene depict officers equipped with riot shields while onlookers observed from a distance. Authorities reported four arrests in connection with the incidents.\n\nLiverpool\n\nLiverpool saw far-right activists clashing with riot police in the vicinity of The Strand, near Liverpool One shopping centre on Saturday. Officers endured attacks by bricks and various projectiles during the demonstration, with the Spellow Hub library also succumbing to fire.\n\nMerseyside Police indicated that a number of officers sustained injuries amid the hostilities. In response to the riots, 33 individuals have been taken into custody.\n\nManchester\n\nFighting between rival groups broke out in the city centre on Saturday. Police officers tried to keep demonstrators apart, but video shared online showed scuffles breaking out in Piccadilly Gardens. A Sainsbury's was then stormed by a gang of masked people, and several of them were heard chanting the name of far-right activist Tommy Robinson. Arrests were made by police.\n\nMiddlesbrough\n\nA group of rioters in Middlesbrough smashed the windows of houses, burnt cars and threw objects at officers on Sunday afternoon, with one seen shouting a racial slur and another telling police: \"It's our f****** country.\" There were 43 arrests, and significant damage was caused to the Crown Court and the University, Cleveland Police said.\n\nNottingham\n\nFar-right and counter-protesters threw objects at one another in the centre of Nottingham. Many of the people involved at the initial protest left and were replaced by people who had no affiliation to either group. Police held both groups away from one another during the majority of the protest, according to local reports. 15 people have been arrested\n\nRotherham\n\nIn some of the worst scenes of the entire weekend, anti-immigration rioters smashed the windows of a Holiday Inn Express believed to be housing asylum seekers, before starting several fires. At least 10 officers were injured, including one who was knocked unconscious, South Yorkshire Police confirmed. They added that one person had already been arrested and others involved should \"expect us to be at their doors very soon\".\n\nDefence Secretary John Healey, who is the local Labour MP, arrived at the scene on Monday to talk to residents about \"the damage they have suffered and the trauma they have suffered\". Mr Healey said: \"This was an estate yesterday that was wracked with shock and fear. Many people in this estate here got holed up in their own homes or felt that they had to get their families out.\"\n\nPortsmouth\n\nHundreds of anti-immigration protesters were met with counter protesters at the steps of the Guildhall on Saturday. It is estimated about 300 people gathered for the short protest this. Police scuffled with protesters as they tried to break up a chase.\n\nStoke-on-Trent\n\nFour men were arrested in Stoke-on-Trent following disorder in the city on Saturday. Police were forced to deny speculation spreading on social media about a person being stabbed.\n\nIn a statement, Staffordshire Police said: \"There is growing speculation that a stabbing has taken place as a result of the disorder today. We can confirm this information is false and no stabbings have been reported to police or emergency responders, despite videos fuelling speculation on social media.\n\n\"We can confirm a man was injured after being hit by a blunt object that was thrown. His injuries are not thought to be serious and he has been taken to hospital for treatment. Four men have been arrested in connection with the disorder and are currently in custody for questioning.\"\n\nSunderland\n\nA police station was burnt in Sunderland on Friday as a planned demonstration quickly turned violent. Damage was also caused across the city centre. Six people have been charged in connection with the disorder.\n\nTamworth\n\nA Holiday Inn hotel was also attacked in Tamworth on Sunday evening, where reports suggested asylum seekers were being housed. People threw petrol bombs, smashed windows, started fires and targeted officers, according to Staffordshire Police.\n\nWeymouth\n\nThree men were arrested following a protest and counter-demonstration on Weymouth seafront, during which two officers were injured. One officer was hit in the face by a thrown bottle and the other was punched in the face during the protest on Sunday, Dorset Police said. Some of those involved were teenagers, with two 15-year-olds issued with dispersal orders.\n\nA force spokesman said: \"Dorset Police have facilitated the two protests along the Esplanade in Weymouth this afternoon and into this evening, balancing the right to protest with minimising disruption to communities.\n\n\"A highly visible presence with a significant number of resources from Dorset Police, as well as officers from Devon and Cornwall, Avon and Somerset, Gloucestershire and Wiltshire, were deployed to the area to ensure the demonstrations were safe and legal - with protesters having now dispersed and left the area. During the evening three arrests were made, with an additional two dispersal orders made against two 15-year-olds from the local area.\"\n\nDon't miss the latest news from around Scotland and beyond. The government would back the police in acting against \"thuggery\" and individuals involved in disorder would \"pay the price\", she said.\n\nMerseyside Police described scenes of \"serious disorder\" in Liverpool on Saturday; several officers were injured after masked protesters threw bricks and chairs at police and rampaged along the city's waterfront.\n\nThe violence was originally sparked by a mass stabbing in Southport, in north-west England, on Monday, in which three girls were killed and eight other children and two adults were injured. Avon and Somerset Police have obtained extra powers to stop, search and disperse people in the city centre due to the demonstrations.\n\nPolice later said they had made multiple arrests due to violent disorder in the city centre.\n\nHull\n\nViolence escalated today with numerous fires being set across the city today as police and firefighters attempted to bring the situation under control. Police later tried to push demonstrators towards the Albert Docks, an area visited by many tourists.\n\nManchester\n\nHundreds arrived in the city centre today with several fights breaking out. According to the Manchester Evening News officers tried to keep demonstrators apart, but video showed scuffles breaking out in Piccadilly Gardens.\n\nA Sainsbury's was stormed by a gang of masked yobs this afternoon with several being heard chanting the name of far-right activist Tommy Robinson.\n\nNottingham\n\nAccording to NottinghamshireLive, both anti-Islam and counter-protesters threw objects at one another. Many of the people involved at the initial protest left and were replaced by people who had no affiliation to either group.\n\nPolice held both groups away from one another during the majority of the protest.\n\nPortsmouth\n\nHundreds of anti-immigration protesters were met with anti-racist demonstrators at the steps of the Guildhall today. It is estimated about 300 people gathered for the short protest this morning.\n\nPolice scuffled with protesters as they tried to break up a chase. A group of young black men objected to the presence of the group, some of whom sang English Defence League chants afterward.\n\nPreston\n\nA Preston City Council spokesperson told people to keep away from the planned protest at the Flag Market. Police denied that there had been a stabbing, countering claims made on social media.\n\nIn a statement, the force said: \"There is growing speculation that a stabbing has taken place as a result of the disorder today. We can confirm this information is false and no stabbings have been reported to police or emergency responders, despite videos fuelling speculation on social media.\n\n\"We can confirm a man was injured after being hit by a blunt object that was thrown. His injuries are not thought to be serious and he has been taken to hospital for treatment. Who Are The Far-Right Groups Behind The Violence? - News18", "body": "Riots involving hundreds of anti-immigration protesters have erupted in towns and cities after false information spread rapidly on social media that the suspect in knife attack at a children's dance class in Southport was a radical Muslim migrant\n\nBritain is seeing the worst outbreak of civil disorder after clashes between anti-immigration demonstrators and counter protesters, following the murder of three young girls in northwest England.\n\nDozens of arrests were made after the scenes of disorder, with police warning that further violence is likely in the coming days.\n\nHome secretary Yvette Cooper said the police would have the government's full support to take the strongest possible action. \"Criminal violence and disorder have no place on Britain's streets,\" she said.\n\nRiots involving hundreds of anti-immigration protesters have erupted in towns and cities after false information spread rapidly on social media that the suspect in Monday's knife attack at a children's dance class in Southport was a radical Muslim migrant.\n\nPolice have said the suspect, Axel Rudakubana, 17, was born in Britain but protests by anti-immigration and anti-Muslim demonstrators have continued, descending into violence, arson and looting.\n\nViolent disorder erupted in Liverpool, Bristol, Hull and Belfast -- four cities located in different corners of the UK -- with scuffles breaking out and bricks and bottles thrown as anti-immigration protesters faced groups opposed to racism, as per a report by Reuters.\n\nMany police officers suffered injuries as they kept several rival protesters from clashing. In Liverpool, two officers were in hospital with suspected facial fractures while another was pushed from his motorbike and assaulted in the disorder involving some 750 protesters and a similar number of rival protesters.\n\nSimilar scenes were witnessed in the southwestern city of Bristol although anti-racist protesters outnumbered anti-immigration groups, with TV footage showing them facing off with police in riot gear.\n\nIn Belfast, some businesses reported damage to property while at least one was set on fire, according to police.\n\nPrime Minister: Keir Starmer is facing his first big test since his election a month ago. Starmer has condemned the violence. He held a meeting of senior ministers on Saturday in which he said police had been given full support to tackle extremists who were attempting \"to sow hate by intimidating communities\". He made clear that the right to freedom of expression and the violent scenes over recent days were \"two very different things\".\n\nHome Secretary: Yvette Cooper said those engaging in violent disorder \"will pay the price\", telling broadcasters \"criminal violence and disorder has no place on Britain's streets\". Cooper said: \"We've been clear to the police that they have our full backing in taking the strongest possible action against perpetrators, including making sure that there are more prosecutors, there are sufficient prison places and also that the courts stand ready because anyone who engages in this kind of disorder needs to be clear that they will pay the price.\"\n\nPolice: Police have warned that further violence is likely in the coming days. \"We know people will try and do this again and policing has been and will continue to be ready,\" said Chief Constable BJ Harrington, who speaks on public order for the National Police Chiefs' Council. Liverpool City region Mayor Steve Rotheram said to \"call out mindless thuggery by people looking for an excuse to spew hatred and carry out acts of violence\". There were no reports of far-right marches in London. Separately, thousands of pro-Palestinian demonstrators marched peacefully through the city to protest Israel's military operation in Gaza.\n\nExperts: Jacob Davey, the director of policy and research for counter-hate at the Institute for Strategic Dialogue in London, quoted The Guardian as saying it was \"a perfect storm\", with a rising far right in the UK emboldened by recent mass demonstrations. The need for urgent political intervention was stressed by the government's independent adviser on political violence and disruption, Lord Walney, who told the Observer that new emergency powers may be needed. \"The system isn't set up to deal with this rolling rabble-rousing being fuelled by far-right actors,\" he said. \"\"I think home office ministers may want to look urgently at a new emergency framework - perhaps temporary in nature - that enables police to use the full powers of arrest to prevent people gathering where there is clear intent to fuel violent disorder,\" as quoted by The Guardian.\n\nAbout two dozen children were attending a summer vacation workshop when an attacker with a knife burst in. Alice Dasilva Aguiar, 9, Elsie Dot Stancombe, 7, and Bebe King, 6, died from their injuries. Ten other people were injured, among whom five girls and two adults are in critical condition.\n\nFar-right demonstrators have launched several violent protests, ostensibly in response to the attack, clashing with police outside a mosque in Southport.\n\nA few hundred protesters hurled beer cans and flares near British PM Starmer's residence in Downing Street in central London on Wednesday evening. More than 100 people were arrested for offenses including violent disorder and assault on an emergency worker, London's Metropolitan Police force said.\n\nBritain's worst attack on children was in 1996, when 43-year-old Thomas Hamilton shot and killed 16 kindergartners and their teacher in a school gymnasium in Dunblane, Scotland. The United Kingdom subsequently banned the private ownership of almost all handguns.\n\nSeveral far-right groups have been at the riots or promoted them on social media. David Miles, a prominent member of Patriotic Alternative, a fascist group, shared photographs of himself in Southport, according to Hope Not Hate, a Britain-based advocacy group that researches extremist organisations.\n\nPolice have said the English Defence League had been involved in the riots. The English Defence League was a far-right street movement created in 2009 notorious for violent protests and anti-Islam and anti-immigration stance.\n\nJoe Mulhall, Hope Not Hate's director of research, called the movement \"post organizational\" in a 2018 analysis. Despite this fact, anti-immigration and anti-Muslim protests quickly erupted in towns and cities across Britain, sparking days of violence.\n\nOn Saturday afternoon, tension was palpable in cities like Liverpool, Leeds, Manchester, and Belfast. Reuters witnesses reported large groups of rival protesters chanting slogans, leading to clashes in certain areas. In Liverpool, eggs, beer cans, and smoke grenades were hurled, while businesses in Belfast suffered property damage.\n\nLiverpool's police reported that multiple officers were injured while handling \"serious disorder\" in the city centre. Meanwhile, authorities in Hull stated that four individuals had been arrested, and three officers were hurt amidst protests involving bottle-throwing.\n\nIn response to the violence, police in Liverpool issued a Section 34 Dispersal Order to combat potential crime. An officer on a motorbike was reportedly kicked off by a demonstrator, with witnesses noting children in tears amidst the chaos as they visited the city centre to see the Disney Magic cruise ship.\n\nAnti-fascist protesters countered the unrest, chanting \"Where's your Tommy gone?\" -- a jab at former English Defence League leader Tommy Robinson. Meanwhile, masked individuals attempted to charge police lines, leading to the introduction of a Section 60 order, granting police increased stop-and-search powers in Liverpool and surrounding areas like Kensington and Toxteth.\n\nThe city of Sunderland in the northeast saw some of the most intense clashes, with riots breaking out on Friday evening.\n\nIn a more extreme display of violence, hundreds of anti-immigration protesters in Sunderland clashed with police, throwing stones and setting vehicles on fire near a mosque. A car was torched, and fires were started near a police station. Four police officers were hospitalised, and 12 people were arrested, according to Chief Police Superintendent Mark Hall. He condemned the acts as \"unforgivable violence and disorder\" rather than legitimate protests.\n\nThe BBC reported at least 30 planned demonstrations across the UK this weekend, with counter-protests organised by anti-racism groups. The situation remains volatile, with police forces on high alert.\n\nIn Stoke-on-Trent, bricks were thrown at officers, while fireworks erupted amid tense exchanges between anti-Islamic protesters and anti-racism demonstrators in Belfast. The windows of a hotel housing migrants in Hull were smashed.\n\nIn Nottingham's Market Square, opposing groups clashed, exchanging bottles and other items. This incident marks Starmer's first major challenge since his election a month ago.\n\nShadow Home Secretary James Cleverly criticised the government's handling of the situation, stating that more needs to be done to restore public order. He called for regular updates and collaboration with tech companies to curb the spread of misinformation, urging that those engaging in violence face the full force of the law.\n\nThis wave of violence is reminiscent of the 2011 riots in Britain, which erupted after a Black man was shot by police in London, resulting in five nights of widespread unrest.\n\nGreater Manchester Police And we will be arresting those responsible.'\n\nAt 9am this morning, hundreds of counter-protesters gathered at Piccadilly Gardens in Manchester ready to face off with the Enough is Enough members.\n\nAround half an hour later, the protesters turned up dressed in balaclavas and England flags.\n\nPolice separated anti-immigration protesters chanting Tommy Robinson's name from the counter-rally organised by anti-hate groups in Manchester.\n\nShocking scenes appeared to show a black man being surrounded and beaten up after he was accosted by crowds of thugs, being kicked in the face before he was surrounded, backed against a wall and beaten.\n\nAfter he was dragged along the floor, police rushed the scene - as violent yobs attempted to get past them and continue to attack him, chanting 'save our kids'.\n\nTwo men have been arrested, one for drunk and disorderly and another after storming into the group of counter-demonstrators.\n\nSome of those attending draped themselves in England flags, while others wore balaclavas and sunglasses to disguise their faces. One attendee waved a sign reading: 'Save our kids'.\n\nGreater Manchester Police later issued a Section 34 dispersal order for the city centre after anti-immigration protesters and counter-demonstrators had to be separated.\n\nThe notice, issued under the Anti-Social Behaviour, Crime and Policing Act 2014 at 11am, gives police the right to order people to leave a specified area if they are committing or are suspected to be committing, anti-social behaviour.\n\nMounted police and lines of officers were pictured containing demonstrators - many of whom wore masks, hats, sunglasses and hoodies.\n\nA number of people reportedly ran into a Sainsbury's and tore through the store.\n\nThere are chants of 'Tommy Robinson' heard from the protesting group - estimated to have around 150 activists - and 'whose streets? our streets' from the counter side, of around 350 people.\n\nMetal fences were seen lying on the floor after protesters ripped them down as riot police and mounted officers rushed in to the crowd, where punches were being thrown.\n\nChants of 'save our kids' and 'we want Starmer out' were also heard from those gathered as the fighting broke out.\n\nSir Keir Starmer said police have the Government's 'full support' to take action against 'extremists' attacking officers and attempting to 'sow hate' as he held crisis talks with ministers over the violence across parts of England.\n\nHome Secretary Yvette Cooper said she would work with forces to help ensure 'consequences, arrests and prosecutions' for those responsible.\n\nShe added that communities have a 'right to feel safe,' as she insisted the police have the Government's full support to take the 'strongest possible action'.\n\nAsked what ministers could do to help counter the violence, the Home Secretary said: 'The police need to lead operations in communities across the country where there has been both violent disorder and thuggery on the streets, which is completely unacceptable, completely damaging and where the police need to, they have our full support, taking the strongest possible action, making sure that these criminals face the full force of the law.\n\n'And also already there are some of the suspects and perpetrators have already been arrested, already facing charges and are in custody, but we expect more of that to continue and we will support the police every step of the way. Communities have a right to be able to feel safe.'\n\nA Downing Street spokesperson said: 'Addressing the scenes of disorder we have seen today, the Prime Minister set out that the police have our full support to take action against extremists on our streets who are attacking police officers, disrupting local businesses and attempting to sow hate by intimidating communities.'\n\nA video shared on social media from Blackburn suggested far-right activists were demanding to see locals' passports.\n\nAnd in Blackpool, cops moved to protect the war memorial, as the iconic Prom was closed. Items were thrown at police vehicles as a police dog tore a flag from two protesters' arms and then tackled a man.\n\nChairs were flung between rioters and punks gathered for the Rebellion festival in the seaside destination.\n\nIn one clash, a man was knocked unconscious when he fell backwards and hit his head on the ground. Another man drove his motorbike at the crowd before officers arrived.\n\nSeparately, police in Belfast this afternoon deployed Land Rovers to keep an 'anti-Islam' protest separated from an anti-racism counter protest. This does not seem to be affiliated with Enough is Enough.\n\nEyewitnesses say protesters chanted 'Islam out' in front of Belfast City Hall as they unfurled Union flags.\n\nThe Police Service of Northern Ireland (PSNI) said they are treating reports of criminal damage as 'hate crimes', and have made two arrests.\n\nThe rally was staged in response to calls on social media for 'anti-Islamic' protests.\n\nThe PSNI previously said it was aware of social media posts calling for protests including 'specific calls to block roads using women and children'.\n\nPSNI officers in riot gear were deployed with 4x4s to keep protesters separated - as fireworks were thrown in the direction of the police.\n\nThe force said on X it was aware of 'several planned protests across Northern Ireland today and will be in attendance to ensure the safety of everyone involved.'\n\nIn a post on X, Northern Ireland Secretary Hilary Benn said: \"Shame on those involved in violent disorder in Belfast today.\n\n\"Hatred has no place in our society. I commend the officers of the PSNI for everything they have done to keep people safe.\"\n\nAt 10am, a small crowd began to gather at Portsmouth's Guildhall in Hampshire.\n\nImages shared on social media showed many of those attending came with England and Union flags, while at least one attendee came with a sign bearing online conspiracy theories.\n\nOthers came with a flag bearing the inscription: 'Stop mass immigration'.\n\nHampshire Constabulary said no incidents have been reported from the demonstration in Portsmouth this morning.\n\nA small but concentrated gathering of people assembled on the steps of the Guildhall in the city centre and were met with a handful of counter-protesters.\n\nIt came after a demonstration outside Potters International Hotel in nearby Aldershot on Wednesday led to disruption as a 'minority' of protesters began shouting racist abuse.\n\nAt 12pm, protesters also began to congregate at Victoria Square in Hull.\n\nJust before 3pm, violence broke out after a protester threw a rock at a line of police officers.\n\nThe protesters seem to be trying to get to asylum seekers in a hotel - smashing the windows - and pelted officers with abuse.\n\nThe riot police began deploying tear gas in the demonstrator's faces.\n\nA spokesperson for Humberside Police said: 'Officers are currently in attendance at a protest that began in Hull City Centre this afternoon, Saturday 3 August.\n\n'A road closure has been put in place on Ferensway and we advise members of the public to avoid the area at this time.'\n\nVideo posted online also shows crowds of people outside of the Royal Hotel, next to Hull train station, with chants of 'get them out' heard. The hotel is one of three used to house asylum seekers in the area.\n\nSocial media was buzzing with locals warning each other to remain vigilant around Hanley in Stoke-on-Trent today.\n\nOne man posted a video warning people to avoid Hanley Town Hall and to 'protect your places of worship' but 'don't engage them in the streets'.\n\nA Facebook user posted: 'Not quite sure what's happening up Hanley and Stoke today regarding the protests but please bear in mind people there are families of many different backgrounds and children out and about today on the school holidays shopping and enjoying the sun.\n\n'We have enough trouble going on on this world, let's not add to it. Stay safe and peaceful.'\n\nLarge crowds were seen gathering in Hanley shortly after 12pm as they marched through the town centre streets.\n\nStoke-on-Trent's MPs came together to condemn the protests in Hanley today, describing the participants as 'far-right extremists'.\n\nMP Gareth Snell posted on Facebook saying 'racism is not patriotism'. Dr Alison Gardner, Stoke-on-Trent South, and David Williams, Stoke-on-Trent North and Kidsgrove added that 'political extremists' were in the city'to spread division and sow the seeds of hate'.\n\nPolice denied that there had been a stabbing, countering claims made on social media.\n\nIn a statement, the force said: 'There is growing speculation that a stabbing has taken place as a result of the disorder today. We can confirm this information is false and no stabbings have been reported to police or emergency responders, despite videos fuelling speculation on social media.\n\n'We can confirm a man was injured after being hit by a blunt object that was thrown. His injuries are not thought to be serious and he has been taken to hospital for treatment.\n\n'Four men have been arrested in connection with the disorder and are currently in custody for questioning.\n\n'A number of protesters have dispersed from the location while a large-scale policing presence with specialist public order resources remain in the area.\n\n'A section 34 dispersal notice has also been authorised, allowing police to disperse people who may return to the area.'\n\nProtesters could be seen facing up to police officers draped in England football flags and Union flags, and covering their faces.\n\nThere are around one hundreds police officers on duty, with several riot vans and dog units deployed to the centre.\n\nChants of 'we hate Nazis' by the anti-protest group were heard outside Hanley Town Hall.\n\nShops in the town centre, particularly along Stafford Street, were advised to close.\n\nIn Leeds, a pro-Palestine counter protest amassed ahead of a planned march organised by English Defence League founder Tommy Robinson.\n\nChants of 'England 'til I die' were heard and the pro-Palestine march replied with 'Nazi scum off our streets'.\n\nAround 150 demonstrators wore St George's Crosses and pro Reform UK placards wearing 'free Tommy Robinson' t-shirts.\n\nLeeds Art Gallery has locked its doors 'for safety purposes' as the clashes occurred right outside its doors.\n\nTensions also erupted in Liverpool this afternoon, as police confirmed a Section 60 Order has been introduced in the city centre and surrounding areas today.\n\nThe Section 60 Order - giving stop and search powers - was put in place at midday and will stay active for a 12-hour period until midnight.\n\nPolice have also put a Section 34 Dispersal Order in place. Under this legislation, officers have the power to seize any item used for anti-social behaviour.\n\nOfficers closed the Strand along the waterfront at 3.30pm in an effort to calm the simmering tensions, while some shops were 'locked down' as thugs flooded the streets.\n\nAn officer was kicked and knocked off his motorbike this afternoon. As it happened, a traffic cone was thrown and a protester held a wooden pole as they shouted 'save our kids'.\n\nPolice separated groups of demonstrators outside the Cunard Building on The Strand in Liverpool.\n\nThe windscreen of a police van was smashed as bricks and plastic barriers were thrown.\n\nBricks were pelted at the vans and officers by youths with their faces covered.\n\nRiot officers then ran at the group to move them back, before backing away as more bricks were thrown.\n\nAnti-fascist protesters sang: 'Where's your Tommy gone?' At one point a group of men with masks and hoods up appeared to try and charge police officers who stood with batons.\n\nOfficers with riot shields and helmets moved the crowd back and cans, bottles and coins were thrown. Police with dogs also moved in to separate the groups.\n\nTwo groups of protesters met at the Pier Head in Liverpool, in front of the Liver Buildings.\n\nChants of 'save our kids' and 'stop the boats' were heard from crowds gathered closer to the waterfront.\n\nRiot vans arrived on Water Street, as police continue to separate opposing protests at the waterfront.\n\nOn one side, crowds are shouting 'where's your Tommy gone?' while the other side is chanting 'get them out' and 'stop the boats', according to the Liverpool Echo.\n\nIn Nottingham, protesters with St George's and union flags in the Market Square have been met with counter-protesters chanting 'racist scum off our streets' and 'Nazis not welcome'.\n\nScuffles broke out at about 3pm, with bottles and other items thrown from both sides.\n\nBut chants of 'England until I die' and 'Tommy Robinson' were drowned out by boos.\n\nShadow home secretary James Cleverly said the Prime Minister and Home Secretary need to 'do more' to restore public order and 'send a clear message to the thugs'.\n\nThe Tory leadership contender said in a statement: 'In opposition Labour voted against public order measures we brought forward to give our police more powers to keep our streets clear, calm and safe, and Keir Starmer taking the knee sent completely the wrong message. There is never a justification for disorder like this.\n\n'Now they are in Government Labour need to clamp down immediately on the violence that we have seen across the country and send a clear message to the thugs that they will be met with the full strength of the law.\n\n'The public expects the Government to restore order. The Prime Minister and Home Secretary must do more to demonstrate that they are gripping this situation.\n\n'They should be giving regular updates alongside the police so potential rioters know that they won't get away with this and they must haul the tech companies in to ensure they are doing everything they can to prevent the spread of disinformation fuelling these events.'\n\nSunderland Central Labour MP Lewis Atkinson said a link could be drawn between the disorder in his constituency on Friday and the ashes of the English Defence League (EDL), which was founded by Tommy Robinson, whose real name is Stephen Yaxley Lennon.\n\nThe EDL has disbanded but its supporters remain active, and Mr Atkinson said evidence suggested a Nazi offshoot of the group was involved in the violence in his constituency on Friday, in which a police station was torched and a mosque attacked.\n\nNorthumbria Police Chief Superintendent Mark Hall said four officers were injured during the violence in the city and 10 people have been arrested.\n\nHe told reporters that those involved in the disorder should 'expect to be met with the full force of the law', adding: 'This was not a protest, this was unforgivable violence and disorder.'\n\nChairman of Mosques and Imams National Advisory Board, Qari Asim, said the Muslim community is 'deeply worried and anxious about the planned protests by the far right groups across the country'.\n\nHe said: 'This intimidation and violence is the inevitable, devastating, outcome of rising Islamophobia that has been enabled to fester on social media, in parts of the mainstream media and by some populist leaders.'\n\nMeanwhile, Tory leadership hopeful Robert Jenrick said 'elements of the far right' appear to be involved in the rioting while fellow contender Priti Patel denounced the 'thuggery' and said MPs should unite in condemnation.\n\nMr Atkinson said he was 'really sad' for Sunderland after a group of 'racists' descended on the city on Friday and attacked police, setting a police station and two cars on fire and targeting a mosque.\n\nHe added: 'A night of idiots will not prevent us from building.'\n\nAsked how the disorder had happened, Mr Atkinson told BBC Radio 4's Today programme that protests had been suggested by people in a number of social media groups in the wake of the Southport stabbings.\n\nHe said: 'The far right, for example Stephen Yaxley Lennon, picked up on those and started promoting those and encouraging known far right individuals to join.'\n\nIndividuals who were involved with the EDL are 'still out there' and need to be kept under surveillance, he said.\n\nMr Jenrick said 'if there is a case' for proscribing the EDL it should be 'considered', when asked by the BBC.\n\nLeadership contender and former home secretary Ms Patel demanded Parliament be recalled over the violence and criticised the Government response, saying: 'Saying the nation is 'braced for disorder' is not only breathtakingly complacent, but both troubling and inadequate.\n\n'The Government is now in danger of appearing to be swept away with events rather than maintaining control of them.'\n\nThousands of people had turned out to pay their respects to Bebe King, six, Elsie Dot Stancombe, seven, and Alice Dasilva Aguiar, nine, at a vigil in Southport on Tuesday.\n\nPrime Minister Sir Keir Starmer later condemned 'thugs' who had travelled to the town to cause unrest.\n\nThe unrest poses the biggest challenge yet of Sir Keir's premiership, evoking the scale of public disorder last seen during the 2011 riots.\n\nThere The National Police Chiefs' Council, which represents law enforcement across Britain, has said that nearly 4,000 additional officers had been deployed to deter the violence.\n\n\"The police have our full backing,\" Yvette Cooper, the British home secretary, said on Saturday. \"I want everyone to be clear. Anyone who gets involved in criminal disorder, violent thuggery on our streets will have to pay the price.\"\n\nTension has gripped some communities across the country after a stabbing rampage at a Taylor Swift-themed dance and yoga class on Monday in the town of Southport, near Liverpool, killed three young girls and injured many others. A 17-year-old suspect was later named.\n\nDisinformation about the attacker's identity spread quickly online, falsely identifying him as a migrant and fueling a violent, far-right riot in which a mosque was attacked and dozens of police officers were injured in Southport on Tuesday.\n\nUnrest has since spread to other parts of Britain, with violent protests in Liverpool, Manchester, Leeds, Nottingham and other cities over the weekend. A protest was also held in Belfast, Northern Ireland, and also turned violent.\n\n\"This week we have seen appalling behavior that in no way shows compassion or respect for the little girls who were killed and injured last week,\" Chief Constable BJ Harrington said on Saturday. \"It shows no respect for our communities, and it will be stopped.\"\n\nIn Liverpool, more than 300 people were involved in what police called a \"violent disorder\" on Saturday night, where businesses were looted and rioters hurled bricks and missiles at police officers. By Sunday morning, at least 11 people had been arrested, the police said.\n\nFar-right protesters and counterprotesters also clashed in Manchester, where the police issued a dispersal order for all demonstrations in parts of the city center. In Nottingham, where multiple demonstrations took place on Saturday, 15 people were arrested in what the police described as a \"largely peaceful\" day.\n\n\"Anyone who comes into the city or our neighborhoods over the coming days to cause any kind of disorder can expect a robust response,\" said Steve Cooper, the deputy chief constable for Nottinghamshire.\n\nThe wave of protests and unrest has been driven by fast-spreading online misinformation, much of it promulgated by far-right voices on the social media platform X and the Telegram messaging app. They include neo-Nazis, violent soccer fans, anti-Muslim factions, and social media influencers who have amplified their messaging to scores of followers.\n\nBy Saturday, unrest had also spread to Northern Ireland, where anti-immigration messaging has simmered across the island over the British government's plan for asylum seekers. The chief constable BJ Harrington warned: \"If you've been involved but haven't been arrested yet, your time will come.\"\n\nOn Saturday afternoon, Sir Keir Starmer held a call from Chequers with key ministers to discuss the latest unrest.\n\nSpeaking afterwards, Yvette Cooper, the home secretary, said: \"We've been clear to the police that they have our full backing in taking the strongest possible action against perpetrators, includ\u00ading making sure that there are more prosecutors, there are sufficient prison places and also that the courts stand ready. Anyone who engages in this kind of disorder needs to be clear that they will pay the price.\"\n\nOn a day of violence:\n\n* Protests descended into violence in Liverpool, Stoke-on-Trent, Hull, Belfast, Blackpool and Leeds.\n\n* At least 26 people were arrested between Friday and Saturday night with many more arrests likely to be announced.\n\n* Four police officers were injured in Sunderland, three in Hull, and in Liverpool two officers were taken to hospital, one with a suspected broken nose and another with a suspected broken jaw after more than 750 people gathered in the city centre and threw bricks and bottles.\n\n* In Bristol, about 200 far-right demonstrators clashed with 500 counter-protesters, with police deploying dogs to quell the violence. Avon and Somerset police said it had made \"multiple arrests\".\n\n* The far-right agitator Tommy Robinson continued to stoke tensions in Britain despite being more than a thousand miles away on holiday, according to an analysis of his social media posts.\n\n* Dame Priti Patel said parliament should be recalled while a fellow Tory leadership contender, James Cleverly, said Starmer should haul in tech companies over misinformation on their platforms.\n\n* Robert Jenrick, another Tory leadership candidate, said that if there was a case for the proscription of the far-right English Defence League, which was founded by Robinson, it should be considered.\n\nContingency plans are being rapidly pulled together by government and law enforcement agencies, amid fears that Britain is heading for violent disorder on a scale last seen during the 2011 riots. Those were triggered by the police shooting of Mark Duggan, a black man, in Tottenham Hale, north London, and over a week spread across London boroughs then into other English cities.\n\nSources have confirmed the blueprint now being drawn up includes the \"additional courts protocol\", which can be deployed in response to an unexpected surge in criminal cases caused by a significant incident.\n\nIt would enable judges to direct magistrates' courts to extend their sitting hours, including overnight and during weekends. It would also provide additional capacity should police forces begin arresting hundreds of protesters, ensuring they could be brought before the courts as quickly as possible.\n\nPolice chiefs are concerned that, otherwise, suspects charged with rioting or violent disorder could still engage in further demonstrations before their hearings and a bail decision is made. Triggering the protocol requires the agreement of the director of public prosecutions, Stephen Parkinson, and the heads of the relevant police forces.\n\nA government spokesman said: \"There are contingency measures in place across the criminal justice system to handle any ... exceptional increases in demand on magistrates' courts.\"\n\nStarmer announced on Thursday that he had established a new violent disorder unit to enable police forces to pull together intelligence and resources to help stamp out unrest led by far-right \"thugs\".\n\nThis weekend the Crown Prosecution Service (CPS) drafted in 70 additional prosecutors, with police forces also providing capacity to deploy more officers from neighbouring forces where there were flashpoints.\n\nAccording to insiders, relaxing the charging thresholds again is also an option. However, there are now concerns about the capacity of the court and prison systems to deal with another 2011-style crisis. Between 2010 and 2018, 162 out of 323 magistrates' courts were closed and the crown courts are still grappling with a backlog from the pandemic.\n\nStarmer was director of public prosecutions during the summer of disorder in 2011. More than 3,000 arrests were made and nearly 1,984 people were charged with offences related to the riots.\n\nThe CPS under Starmer's leadership was praised for its response, which included the introduction of 24/7 night courts, a relaxing of the thresholds to determine whether to press charges, and a push for longer jail sentences. In the aftermath of the trouble, the additional courts protocol was drawn up to formalise how the courts and judiciary could respond to similar crises in future.\n\nIt has not been used since, but a government source said that the Ministry of Justice had held discussions with the judiciary, which had indicated a willingness to use it should rioting escalate. More than 100 people have been arrested since the disorder first broke out last week.\n\nIn Liverpool a group of protesters gathered around a female police officer lying injured on the ground. \"Any more pictures and I'll charge \u00a35 a time,\" shouted one thug. \"How many more kids will have to be raped because you won't listen?\" shouted another man. \"She f***ing deserves it,\" yelled a woman with a local accent.\n\nWave after wave of protesters clashed with police by the Liver Building on the city's waterfront, with masked men throwing bricks, bottles and chairs.\n\nAround the country video on social media showed looting, including at a Sainsbury's in Manchester, a JD Sports in Blackpool and an O2 shop in Hull.\n\nIn Hull, three police officers were hurt and at least four people were arrested after thugs descended on a hotel that has been used to accommodate asylum seekers after a protest earlier in the day. Riot police formed a protective cordon around the Royal Station hotel after bricks and bottles were thrown at its windows. Some protesters could be heard chanting: \"Get them out.\"\n\nIn Stoke-on-Trent, a group of far-right protesters stormed the Masjid Salahuddin mosque in the Hanley area, throwing bricks at police and worshippers. Masked counter-protesters carrying batons and metal rods retaliated, leaving at least two members of the far-right group requiring medical attention for head injuries. Staffordshire police said four men had been arrested but put out a statement to counter claims that a stabbing had taken place after speculation on social media.\n\nPatel said the government appeared in danger of being \"swept away with events rather than maintaining control of them\". Calling for parliament to be recalled immediately, she added: \"Now is a moment for national reflection and solidarity ... we either believe in the rule of law, or we do not.\"", "source": {"uri": Footage posted online showed a bin being set on fire outside the hotel and demonstrators smashing their way inside.\n\nIt was the latest disruption after several nights of unrest triggered by the killing of three girls in the Lancashire town of Southport on Monday, and came hours after Prime Minister Sir Keir Starmer warned that \"violence committed by a small minority of thugs\" would be met with the full weight of the law.\n\nThe protests are the most widespread eruption of far-right violence in the UK for years, and have been fuelled by a torrent of Islamophobic and anti-immigrant misinformation spread on social media by far-right influencers since the mass stabbing in Southport.\n\nMore than 90 people were arrested on Saturday after violent gatherings in several towns and cities including Bristol, Blackpool, Hull and Liverpool, according to various regional police forces.\n\nJudges were on Sunday considering keeping courts open all night to work through the backlog of cases, as they did in the wake of the 2011 riots that resulted in thousands of arrests and prosecutions.\n\nIn Bolton, Greater Manchester, police issued a dispersal order on Sunday afternoon as several hundred demonstrators and counter demonstrators gathered in the town hall square.\n\nMissiles were thrown as tensions escalated and the protests spilled out across the town centre, with the two sides confronting one another while police attempted to keep them separate.\n\nAround 300 protesters marched through Middlesbrough in North Yorkshire on Sunday afternoon before breaking through a police line in the city centre and throwing projectiles including pieces of slate and plastic bottles.\n\nStarmer held emergency talks with ministers this weekend to discuss the riots spurred by far-right agitators. communities.\n\nThe National Police Chiefs' Council said 4,000 extra officers were in place across the country to deal with any further outbreaks of violence.\n\nShadow home secretary James Cleverly Footage posted online showed a bin being set on fire outside the hotel and demonstrators smashing their way inside.\n\nHome secretary Yvette Cooper said the demonstrators had \"deliberately\" set fire to the building \"with people known to be inside\" and urged police to take \"the strongest action against those responsible\".\n\nIn Bolton, Greater Manchester, police issued a dispersal order on Sunday afternoon as several hundred demonstrators and counter-demonstrators gathered in the town hall square.\n\nMissiles were thrown as tensions escalated and the protests spilled out across the town centre, with the two sides confronting one another while police attempted to keep them separate.\n\nAbout 300 protesters marched through Middlesbrough in North Yorkshire on Sunday afternoon before breaking through a police line in the city centre, throwing projectiles including pieces of slate and plastic bottles, and smashing up cars, police vans and buildings.\n\nAhead of the gathering, calls to stage a full-scale riot had circulated online. Cleveland police said they were dealing with disorder in the town and had made a \"number of arrests\".\n\nThe latest disruptions came hours after Prime Minister Sir Keir Starmer warned that \"violence committed by a small minority of thugs\" would be met with the full weight of the law.\n\nMore than 100 people were arrested on Saturday after violent gatherings in several towns and cities including Bristol, Blackpool, Hull and Liverpool, according to various regional police forces.\n\nJudges were on Sunday considering keeping courts open all night to work through the backlog of cases, as they did in the wake of the 2011 riots that resulted in thousands of arrests and prosecutions.\n\nStarmer held emergency talks with ministers this weekend to discuss the riots spurred by far-right agitators. He said the right to freedom of expression and violent disorder were \"two very different things\" and labelled participants \"extremists\".\n\nThe prime minister said the government backed the police to \"take all necessary action\" to keep Britain's streets safe after attacks on police officers, disruption to local businesses and what he said were attempts to sow hate by intimidating communities.\n\nThe National Police Chiefs' Council said 4,000 extra officers were in place across the country to deal with any further outbreaks of violence.\n\nSouth Yorkshire mayor Oliver Coppard More are also expected in Rushmoor, Weymouth, Middlesborough and Lancaster this afternoon.\n\nMailOnline looks at all the violent protests that have taken place since Friday night.\n\nThis afternoon a violent protest erupts outside a migrant hotel in Rotherham\n\nHundreds of protesters are marching the streets of Hanley as the town is crawling with riot police\n\nA car is toppled over and set alight during scenes of disorder in Sunderland on Friday\n\nRiot police in Sunderland seen on Friday night ahead of clashes with hundreds of protests\n\nSunderland\n\nSunderland became subjected to carnage on Friday night when riots tore through the city.\n\nA police station was set on fire and many officers were injured with two being taken to hospital.\n\nViolent blows were dealt between officers and protestors, as bricks and beer cans were flung through the air, and cars were flipped and set alight.\n\nAmong the hundreds taking to the street in the north east town was a shirtless man with a Nazi tattoo emblazoned across his chest.\n\nThe topless man was filmed launching into a racist tirade, saying: 'This time in your own f***ing country if you're ashamed to be f***ing white and be an Englishman... f*** off.'\n\nMeanwhile an officer desperately fighting to maintain order as the violence spiralled out of control admitted: 'That was bad tonight.'\n\nSince then, at least 12 arrests have been made by Northumbria Police who dramatically smashed down the front door of a suspected rioter yesterday.\n\nA police officer breaks down a door in Sunderland to make an arrest after a night of horrendous violence in the city\n\nIn the footage a topless man can be seen approaching a wall of police officers, dressed in riot gear and armed with shields, who are surrounded by protesters who can be heard shouting expletives\n\nA police car set on fire in Sunderland. police.\n\nProtesters sang Rule Britannia, 'England 'til I die' and 'we want our country back', with their actions being described as nothing more than 'thuggery'.\n\nMeanwhile, a counter protester from an anti-racism demonstration, was reportedly hit on the back of the head with a bottle.\n\nPolice made 14 arrests because of violent disorder in the city centre, which Avon and Somerset Police Stay safe and peaceful,' he said.\n\nLarge crowds were seen gathering in Hanley shortly after 12pm, with shops in the city centre being advised to close.\n\nStoke-on-Trent's MPs came together to condemn the protests in Hanley today, describing the participants as 'far-right extremists'.\n\nProtesters were seen facing up to police officers draped in England football flags and Union flags, and covering their faces.\n\nChants of 'we hate Nazis' by the anti-protest group were heard outside Hanley Town Hall.\n\nStaffordshire Police said it made 10 arrests following the disorder which saw missiles flung into the air.\n\nNottingham\n\nProtesters also gathered in Nottingham city centre with bottles and cans being thrown at counter demonstrators.\n\nRioters with St George's and union flags in Nottingham's Market Square have been met with counter-protesters chanting 'racist scum off our streets' and 'Nazis not welcome'.\n\nScuffles broke out as opposing groups faced each other on King Street at about 3pm, with bottles and other items thrown from both sides.\n\nChants of 'England until I die' and 'Tommy Robinson' were drowned out by boos from the counter-protesters.\n\nPolice officers detain a woman during a protest in Nottingham Market Square this afternoon\n\nBlackpool and Blackburn\n\nFar-right protesters also gathered in Blackpool on Saturday with skirmishes breaking out between demonstrators and punks.\n\nIn one clash, a man was knocked unconscious when he fell backwards and hit his head on the ground. Another man drove his motorbike at the crowd before officers arrived.\n\nIt led to police issuing a Section 34 dispersal zone in the city, writing that while it expected most protesters to 'express Some rioters hurled pieces of wood, bottles and chairs, and sprayed fire extinguishers at police officers. At least one injured officer in riot gear was carried away by colleagues.\n\nFootage from the scene showed a bin on fire and protesters, some draped in St George and union flags, chanting: \"Get them out.\" The demonstrators appeared at one point to storm into the hotel, with reports of a fire inside, and people peering out of windows.\n\nYvette Cooper, the home secretary, condemned the rioters, saying: \"The criminal, violent attack on a hotel housing asylum seekers in Rotherham is utterly appalling. Deliberately setting fire to a building with people known to be inside.\n\n\"South Yorkshire police have full government support for the strongest action against those responsible.\"\n\nProtests on Sunday were also planned in Bolton, Lancaster, Weymouth and Middlesbrough where more than 300 protesters marched through the city centre, chanting: \"We want our country back\".\n\nThe rioters in Middlesbrough threw bricks, cans and pots at police, and pushed burning wheelie bins at a line of officers with shields, leaving a road strewn with smoking rubbish.\n\nOne group walked through a residential area smashing the windows of houses and cars. The orders were put in place at 2pm on Sunday and will stay active for a 12-hour period.\n\nGreater Manchester police said section 60 and section 60AA orders have been authorised across Bolton until 10pm on Sunday, after an early section 34 dispersal notice. A section 60AA requires people to remove face coverings used to disguise or conceal their appearance.\n\nRioting and disorder has continued in the wake of the killing of three young girls at a Taylor Swift-themed dance class in Southport on Monday.\n\nAxel Rudakubana, 17, from Lancashire, is accused of the attack, but false claims were spread online that the suspect was an asylum seeker who had arrived in the UK by boat. In the wake of these messages, far-right protesters - guided by social media - have gathered in towns and cities across the country.\n\nAt least 100 people were arrested after violence on Saturday in Hull, Liverpool, Stoke-on-Trent, Nottingham, Bristol, Manchester, Blackpool and Belfast.\n\nSeveral police officers were injured, shops were looted and a library providing support for one of the most deprived communities in the country was set on fire.\n\nBut volunteers armed with brushes and bin bags joined council crews who worked through the night to reopen the streets.\n\n\"Yesterday we saw the worst of Hull but already today we have seen the best,\" councillor Jack Haines of Hull city council said on Sunday as he thanked the \"selfless\" volunteers.\n\nThe community also rallied together to help council workers in County Road, Walton, where the ground floor of Spellow Lane Library Hub suffered severe fire damage. Shelves of books were knocked over at the library which was due to host a programme of activities for young people in August and adult learning courses in September.\n\n\"I want to pay tribute to Merseyside police, the emergency services and Liverpool city council staff for their fast response in cleaning up, and also to those residents who came out to help - it has been heartening to see, and that is the real spirit of our city,\" said councillor Liam Robinson, the leader of Liverpool city council.\n\n\"The violence we have seen on our streets is the manipulation of tragic events, an attack on our community by wanton criminals. We can't allow a minority of mindless thugs to win. They are not representative of our city and we will be working with partners to ensure the perpetrators are swiftly brought to justice.\n\n\"Our priority is to assess the damage to Spellow Library and to bring it back into use as quickly as possible.\"\n\nFaith leaders across Merseyside said that communities who have been hard hit by the Southport killings and the violence that has spread afterwards are trying to rebuild.\n\nIn a joint statement, they said: \"The people of all faiths and none who came out to sweep the streets, to rebuild walls and have so generously donated money in memory of those three girls: that is the spirit that will help us through this incredibly challenging time.\n\n\"While the events of this week may continue to shake our belief in humanity, it remains intact.\n\n\"We need to remain calm and peaceful at this time and, as faith leaders, we are united in our desire for peace and justice. Now is the time to take pride in our community spirit again.\n\n\"Within our different communities we pray for all those affected. Internewscast Journal", "body": "Ex-cops have pleaded with the government to give the police water cannons to beat rioting mobs, after a day where hordes of violent thugs rampaged across Britain's cities.\n\nThe veteran officers said it was time to decide whether the country needs a police force or a police service - as they pleaded for decisive action to bring order back to the country's besieged streets.\n\nAnd they welcomed news that courts could sit overnight to sentence thugs in a plan which carries echoes of the battle to restore peace during the 2011 riots.\n\nYesterday, anarchy swept the UK in apocalyptic scenes across major cities and towns, as rioters threw bricks at police, cars were torched and shops were ransacked in a feeding frenzy of looting.\n\nBrave police officers were hospitalised as they stood in the way of waves of vile thugs as they desperately fought to keep order, with some recording broken jaws and noses.\n\nOne shocking photo showed a shell-shocked officer staring into the camera as her colleagues tended to her, while further video saw a lone cop forced off his motorbike and beaten by a gang of thugs in Liverpool.\n\nAnd cops are bracing themselves for more disorder in the coming days as the National Police Chiefs Council say they will bring in 4,000 extra officers to deal with the 'violent thugs'.\n\nIt came after tensions fueled by misinformation boiled over following the mass stabbing in Southport - with mayhem breaking out in towns and cities across the country.\n\nKevin Moore, the former Detective Chief Superintendent of Sussex Police CID, told MailOnline that police forces must act with force to eradicate the chaos.\n\nHe said: 'If you look at the tactics used by European police forces they don't mess around.\n\n'It's a hot summer at the moment - they'd be wheeling out the old water cannon and sorting it all out.\n\n'I think that the public and the government need to decide what sort of police force they want - whether they want one that's going to enforce the law and maintain the King's peace, or whether they want this quasi police service where we are all very nice to everyone but that is totally and utterly ineffective.'\n\nHome Secretary Yvette Cooper said yesterday that people involved in the clashes 'will pay the price' and that 'criminal violence and disorder has no place on Britain's streets'.\n\nAnd Prime Minister Sir Keir Starmer said the police have his 'full support' to take action against 'extremists' attempting to 'sow hate' by intimidating communities as he held emergency talks with ministers over the unrest in parts of England.\n\nArrests have been made across the country with police warning of more to come once CCTV, social media and body-worn camera footage has been scoured.\n\nBut Mr Moore slammed the government - saying it is time to recall parliament and focus on the issue, as he warned that an expectation that the depleted police force will be able to deal with the riots is 'unrealistic'.\n\nHe continued: 'One of the things that concerns me is that within the last week, Parliament has gone off on four weeks slumber. Why? Why is the prime minister not considering recalling parliament? Because something needs to happen.\n\n'There is a limit to how many police officers you can move around the country. I tell you, the first place that these police officers that they want to send all over the country will come from is neighborhood policing.\n\n'And then what happens? Well, the service that the public get is appalling because there are no police officers out there to deliver it.\n\n'The government seem to think this is as easy as snapping your fingers, and all of these police officers are going to get magicked out of cupboards. It's totally unrealistic. It's just not going to happen.'\n\nThere was violence on Saturday in towns and cities such as Hull, Liverpool, Stoke-on-Trent, Nottingham, Bristol, Manchester, Blackpool and Belfast which saw several police officers injured. It followed a riot on Sunderland on Friday evening.\n\nIn Liverpool there were 11 arrests and a number of officers injured, with one being hit on the head by a chair. One officer was treated in hospital for a suspected broken jaw and another for a suspected broken nose.\n\nAnother officer was kicked and knocked off his motorcycle by a demonstrator and others tried to kick riot shields.\n\nBrian Booth, the Acting National Deputy Chair of Police Federation, welcomed the news that courts could sit throughout the day and night to bring more offenders to justice - saying it would be a serious deterrent.\n\nHe explained that he had he had 'no issue' with water cannons - but believes there are not enough available in the UK to have enough effect.\n\nHimself a veteran of Bradford and the 2011 riots, he said: 'I think the biggest key is we've got to make an absolute deterrent, and also make sure we've got Fast Track courts.\n\n'Start showing people that we're not messing about, sending people to prison. Showing if you're going to get involved in the highest level of disorder - rioting - there are consequences.\n\n'I think a few quick hits and a lot of public attention around that will be the deterrent that probably starts to win.'\n\nIn response to reports that magistrates courts could sit 24/7 in response to the riots, a Government spokesperson said: 'There are contingency measures in place across the criminal justice system, to handle any unexpected and exceptional increases in demand on magistrates' courts.'\n\nWhen a major incident causes a sudden surge in criminal gases the Chief Officer of Police and the Chief Crown Prosecutor can request additional court sessions.\n\nThe process was used in 2011, when Sir Keir Starmer was Director of Public Prosecutions, and saw courts open throughout the night to process offenders.\n\nThe riots of that year - sparked after Mark Duggan, a black man, was shot dead by police - saw around 3,000 people arrested across cities including London, Birmingham, Coventry, Leicester and Nottingham.\n\nBut Mr Booth added that drafting in officers from across the country will have an impact on future cases and will mean everyday inquiries will be processed slower.\n\nAnd he said the effect of being pummeled by the very people they have been working to protect will have an 'awful' effect on morale, particularly after they did a 'really good job' in response to the horrific stabbing in Southport.\n\nHe said: 'These officers aren't just magicked out of out of nowhere, and there's no impact. These officers are the ones that are carrying a normal workload or investigating crimes already.\n\n'These are the officers who are being dragged back off annual leave or off their rest days and in the future, that will have an impact.\n\n'The general public are going to suffer in the in the sense that officers are being distracted from their normal duties.\n\n'It's awful because we've become the focus of everyone's ills. The police are now becoming the targets of everyone's anger, and it's nothing they've done.\n\n'They've actually gone out and done a really good job bringing the alleged offender to justice, gathering the the evidence and dealing with a very upset public. But now becoming the target of the bricks and the stakes and the hatred.'\n\nThe riots in cities including London and Hartlepool are thought to be triggered by misinformation spread online as to the identity of the teenager suspected of killing Bebe King, six, Elsie Dot Stancombe, seven, and Alice Dasilva Aguiar, nine.\n\nAxel Rudakubana, 17, who was born in Cardiff to Rwandan parents, was eventually named as the suspect in a bid to stop the chaos.\n\nSouthport locals - including Elsie's mother - have desperately pleaded for the violence to stop to no avail.\n\nShocking images show cars and shops torched on the streets of Hull, while footage appeared to show demonstrators rushing an Asian man in his car as they shouted 'p***', smashing his window as clouds of black smoke billowed overhead.\n\nRunning clashes between the mob and officers in the Liverpool left families visiting to see a Disney Princess cruise ship fleeing in terror from gangs of thugs.\n\nHooligans torched the city's new Spellow Hub library, which had only opened last year. Video footage showed vandals rampaging outside the facility, as flames rose into the night sky.\n\nUnverified reports on social media suggested a man was stabbed in Hanley, Stoke-on-Trent. However, Staffordshire Police denied that an attack had taken place in the town, with no stabbings reported to cops or emergency services.\n\nFootage posted online showed groups of Muslims gathering to 'defend mosques'. Many appeared to be carrying sticks, though they said they were in the city 'peacefully'.\n\nMajor violence unfolded in Manchester when a massive brawl was swiftly broken up by officers wielding batons after a man allegedly threw a flare. Protesters tore down fences to hurl at other demonstrators as police put themselves between rival groups.\n\nFootage showed men clutching cups of alcohol shouting and jeering as others jumped into a jumbled fight, each side grappling one another and ripping clothing.\n\nIn Hull, tear gas was deployed against demonstrators who smashed the windows of a hotel housing asylum seekers. Three officers were injured and four arrests were made, Humberside Police said.\n\nShocking scenes from the Yorkshire city appeared to show an Asian man attacked after he reversed into a fence trying to escape the mob - while cars were torched and vandalised in an afternoon of rampant chaos.\n\nOver 400 counter-protesters also massed in Cardiff, including Black Lives Matter and Stand Up to Racism, in contrast to a small number of demonstrators.\n\nFourteen people were arrested in Bristol, as shocking images showed beer kegs being thrown at police cars and windows being smashed by hurled projectiles.\n\nA video shared on social media from Blackburn suggested far-right activists were demanding to see locals' passports.\n\nAnd in Blackpool, cops moved to protect the war memorial, as the iconic Prom was closed. Items were thrown at police vehicles as a police dog tore a flag from two protesters' arms and then tackled a man.\n\nChairs were flung between rioters and punks gathered for the Rebellion festival in the seaside destination.\n\nIn one clash, a man was knocked unconscious when he fell backwards and hit his head on the ground. Another man drove his motorbike at the crowd before officers arrived.\n\nSeparately, police in Belfast deployed Land Rovers to keep an 'anti-Islam' protest separated from an anti-racism counter protest. Eyewitnesses said protesters chanted 'Islam out' in front of Belfast City Hall as they unfurled Union flags.\n\nThe Police Service of Northern Ireland (PSNI) said they are treating reports of criminal damage as 'hate crimes', and made two arrests. Later in the night, officers responded after a building was set on fire.\n\nAt 10am, a small crowd also gathered at Portsmouth's Guildhall in Hampshire.\n\nMore than 35 'Enough is Enough' demonstrations are planned across the UK this weekend, with several counter-protests by groups such as Unite Against Fascism and Stand Up to Racism also set to take place.\n\nThe violence came alongside wide-spread looting, with shops across the UK ransacked as yobs took advantage of the chaos sweeping the country.\n\nWine, phones and phones were ripped from the shelves of every-day stores as brazen demonstrators profited from the anarchy, having smashed the windows with bricks and stones.\n\nMore shops were beaten and even torched by gangs of masked yobs, with blazes ripping through ordinary people's livelihoods as anti-immigration demonstrations spiralled out of control.\n\nAnd police say this could only be the beginning - with forces bracing for more disorder in the coming days.\n\nChief Constable BJ Harrington, who speaks on public order for the National Police Chiefs' Council, said in a statement: 'This week we have seen appalling behaviour that in no way shows compassion or respect for the little girls who were killed and injured last week. It shows no respect for our communities, and it will be stopped.\n\n'We know people will try and do this again in the coming days and policing has been and will continue to be ready.\n\n'There are 130 extra units in place across the country, meaning almost 4,000 extra public order-trained officers to deploy.\n\n'So if you're planning to cause trouble and disorder our message is very simple - we'll be watching you. Anyone committing a criminal offence will be detained and brought before the courts.\n\n'In recent days we have seen criminals masquerading as protesters, causing senseless destruction.\n\n'These young girls at a Taylor Swift-themed holiday club in Southport on Monday.\n\nManchester, Belfast, Liverpool and Leeds all saw far right and counter protests today, but it was last night's disorder in Sunderland that was particularly violent.\n\nPolice officers were attacked, a police station and two cars were set on fire and a mosque was targeted.\n\nAt least eight people have been arrested for a range of offences, including violent disorder and burglary, said Northumberland Police.\n\nHome Secretary Yvette Cooper said 'criminal violence and disorder has no place on Britain's streets'.\n\nShe he believes a Nazi offshoot of the now disbanded English Defence League (EDL), led by Tommy Robinson, were involved in last night's violence.\n\nAsked how the disorder had happened, Mr Atkinson told need.'.\n\nMeanwhile, fellow Conservative leadership contender and former home secretary Priti Patel demanded Parliament be recalled over the violence and criticised the government response, warning:
